instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree defines a sequence of actions for a resource-gathering robot. The robot is programmed to perform the following actions in sequence: 
1. Move towards the closest available resource.
2. Wait for 30 frames.
3. Perform resource mining based on specific parameters.
4. Mine the identified resource.

Additionally, the tree includes various other potential actions and conditions such as "dumpRun", "go1", "go2", "go3", "isFull", "mineResources", "moveBaseToGoal", "stay1", "stay2", and different types of "waitFrames" actions with varying parameters.

Overall, the behavior tree outlines the decision-making process and actions for the robot to efficiently gather resources while considering factors like resource availability and operational pauses.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Sequence name="Sequence1">
            <Action ID="goClosestR"/>
            <Action ID="waitFrames2" frames="30"/>
            <Action ID="waitFrames3" d_one="4" d_zero="" frames="{pauseAtMine}" stagger="{sight}"/>
            <Action ID="mineResource"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="dumpRun"/>
        <Action ID="go1"/>
        <Action ID="go2"/>
        <Action ID="go3"/>
        <Action ID="goClosestR"/>
        <Condition ID="isFull"/>
        <Action ID="mineResource"/>
        <Action ID="mineResources"/>
        <Action ID="moveBaseToGoal">
            <input_port name="key_name">goal</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="stay1"/>
        <Action ID="stay2"/>
        <Action ID="waitFrames">
            <output_port name="barout"/>
            <input_port name="baz"/>
            <input_port name="fooin"/>
            <input_port default="15" name="frames">frames</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="waitFrames2">
            <input_port default="15" name="frames">frames</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="waitFrames3">
            <inout_port default="4" name="d_one">has default</inout_port>
            <inout_port name="d_zero">d1</inout_port>
            <input_port default="2" name="frames"/>
            <input_port name="stagger">not a real argument, the other has a default</input_port>
        </Action>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed for a robot to navigate through an environment with periodic global path replanning at 1 Hz and includes recovery actions. The robot will attempt to navigate to a goal pose, using a grid-based planner, and clear the global costmap. If this fails, it will follow a predefined path and clear the local costmap. In case of further failures, it will execute recovery actions such as clearing both the global and local costmaps, spinning, and waiting.

Overall, the behavior tree ensures that the robot continuously attempts navigation while handling potential failures by reattempting navigation, following a predefined path, and executing recovery actions. This robust approach allows the robot to adapt to changing environments and recover from unexpected obstacles or errors in its navigation process.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz and it also has
  recovery actions.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="6" name="NavigateRecovery">
      <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
        <RateController hz="1.0">
          <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="ComputePathToPose">
            <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
          </RecoveryNode>
        </RateController>
        <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="FollowPath">
          <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>
          <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
        </RecoveryNode>
      </PipelineSequence>
      <ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
        <GoalUpdated/>
        <SequenceStar name="RecoveryActions">
          <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
          <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
          <Spin spin_dist="1.57"/>
          <Wait wait_duration="5"/>
        </SequenceStar>
      </ReactiveFallback>
    </RecoveryNode>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates a robot's movement towards three different goals (Goal_a, Goal_b, Goal_c) in a repeated sequence for 3 cycles. 
For each cycle, the robot sets the blackboard with the coordinates of the three goals and then moves towards each goal sequentially using the "MoveRobot" behavior tree. After reaching each goal, it takes a snapshot using the SnapshotClient.
This process is repeated for the specified number of cycles. The "MoveRobot" behavior tree itself involves setting a goal for the robot using Nav2Client.

Overall, the behavior tree controls the robot's navigation by repeatedly moving it to predefined locations while capturing snapshots at each location.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute = "MainTree">
    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <Repeat num_cycles="3">
            <Sequence>
                <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_a" value="-0.579;-1.341;0.0;1.0" />
                <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_b" value="5.214;-1.533;0.0;1.0" />
                <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_c" value="-1.588;1.253;0.0;1.0" />
                <Sequence>
                    <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_a" />
                    <SnapshotClient/>
                    <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_b" />
                    <SnapshotClient/>
                    <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_c" />
                    <SnapshotClient/>
                </Sequence>
            </Sequence>
        </Repeat>
    </BehaviorTree>

    <BehaviorTree ID="MoveRobot">
        <Sequence name="SetGoal">
            <Nav2Client goal="{target}" />
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed for a robot to navigate through an array of poses, continuously replanning its global path at 1 Hz. It includes recovery actions specific to planning/control and general system issues. The main sequence involves the robot navigating with periodic replanning, using a rate controller to manage the frequency of path computation and following the path. If there are failures during navigation, it retries a limited number of times before executing recovery actions such as clearing the costmaps, spinning, waiting, and backing up.

In summary, the behavior tree orchestrates the robot's navigation by continuously updating its path through poses, handling potential failures in path computation and execution, and incorporating recovery strategies to address various issues that may arise during navigation.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz through an array of poses continuously
   and it also has recovery actions specific to planning / control as well as general system issues.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="6" name="NavigateRecovery">
      <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
        <RateController hz="0.333">
          <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="ComputePathThroughPoses">
            <ReactiveSequence>
              <RemovePassedGoals input_goals="{goals}" output_goals="{goals}" radius="0.5"/>
              <ComputePathThroughPoses goals="{goals}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
            </ReactiveSequence>
            <ReactiveFallback name="ComputePathThroughPosesRecoveryFallback">
              <GoalUpdated/>
              <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
            </ReactiveFallback>
          </RecoveryNode>
        </RateController>
        <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="FollowPath">
          <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>
          <ReactiveFallback name="FollowPathRecoveryFallback">
            <GoalUpdated/>
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
          </ReactiveFallback>
        </RecoveryNode>
      </PipelineSequence>
      <ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
        <GoalUpdated/>
        <RoundRobin name="RecoveryActions">
          <Sequence name="ClearingActions">
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
          </Sequence>
          <Spin spin_dist="1.57"/>
          <Wait wait_duration="5"/>
          <BackUp backup_dist="0.15" backup_speed="0.025"/>
        </RoundRobin>
      </ReactiveFallback>
    </RecoveryNode>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed for a robot's navigation system, focusing on continuous global path replanning at 1 Hz and incorporating recovery actions for planning, control, and general system issues. The main sequence involves navigating with periodic replanning, where the robot computes a path to a specified goal using a grid-based planner, follows the computed path using a specific controller, and handles recovery in case of failures during planning or execution.

The recovery mechanism includes retrying failed navigation tasks, reacting to updated goals, clearing costmaps (both local and global), spinning to reorient, waiting for a duration, and backing up if necessary. These recovery actions are organized into a structured fallback approach, ensuring that the robot can handle various types of issues that may arise during navigation.

Overall, the behavior tree provides a robust framework for the robot's navigation system, enabling it to continuously plan and execute paths while handling potential failures and system issues effectively.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz and it also has
  recovery actions specific to planning / control as well as general system issues.
  This will be continuous if a kinematically valid planner is selected.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="6" name="NavigateRecovery">
      <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
        <RateController hz="1.0">
          <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="ComputePathToPose">
            <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
            <ReactiveFallback name="ComputePathToPoseRecoveryFallback">
              <GoalUpdated/>
              <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
            </ReactiveFallback>
          </RecoveryNode>
        </RateController>
        <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="FollowPath">
          <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>
          <ReactiveFallback name="FollowPathRecoveryFallback">
            <GoalUpdated/>
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
          </ReactiveFallback>
        </RecoveryNode>
      </PipelineSequence>
      <ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
        <GoalUpdated/>
        <RoundRobin name="RecoveryActions">
          <Sequence name="ClearingActions">
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
          </Sequence>
          <Spin spin_dist="1.57"/>
          <Wait wait_duration="5"/>
          <BackUp backup_dist="0.15" backup_speed="0.025"/>
        </RoundRobin>
      </ReactiveFallback>
    </RecoveryNode>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed for a robot to navigate a global path with periodic replanning at 1 Hz and includes recovery actions. It uses a pipeline sequence to manage the navigation process, with recovery nodes for handling potential failures.

The "NavigateWithReplanning" sequence incorporates a rate controller to ensure the replanning occurs at the specified frequency. Within this sequence, there are recovery nodes for computing the path to a pose and following the path. These recovery nodes contain fallback behaviors such as clearing costmaps and waiting in case of issues.

If any of the recovery nodes fail, the "RecoveryFallback" handles the situation by waiting for a set duration before attempting recovery again. This structure ensures that the robot can continuously navigate its environment, recompute paths when necessary, and recover from unexpected obstacles or errors.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz and it also has
  recovery actions.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="2" name="NavigateRecovery">
      <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
        <RateController hz="1.0">
          <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="4" name="ComputePathToPose">
            <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
            <ReactiveFallback name="PathToPoseFallback">
              <GoalUpdated/>
              <RoundRobin name="GlobalPlannerRecoveryActions">
                <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
                <Wait wait_duration="2"/>
              </RoundRobin>
            </ReactiveFallback>
          </RecoveryNode>
        </RateController>
        <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="4" name="FollowPath">
          <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>
          <ReactiveFallback name="FollowPathFallback">
            <GoalUpdated/>
            <RoundRobin name="PlannerRecoveryActions">
              <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
              <Spin spin_dist="1.57"/>
            </RoundRobin>
          </ReactiveFallback>
        </RecoveryNode>
      </PipelineSequence>
      <ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
        <GoalUpdated/>
        <Wait wait_duration="5"/>
      </ReactiveFallback>
    </RecoveryNode>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree represents a complex sequence of actions for controlling a robotic system. It involves multiple sub-trees, each responsible for specific tasks such as planning paths, moving manipulators, handling objects, and navigating the vehicle. The overall task can be summarized as follows:

The "TestNav" behavior tree orchestrates a series of actions for the robotic system. It begins with opening the gripper, navigating the vehicle, and then executing a sequence of manipulator movements to search specific frames, carry an object, and return to a designated drive position. Additionally, it includes error handling and recovery mechanisms, such as dealing with failure scenarios when handling objects or finding empty frames.

The behavior tree is designed to handle various scenarios in a structured manner, ensuring that the robot performs the necessary actions to accomplish its objectives while also addressing potential failures during the process.

<root main_tree_to_execute="TestNav">

    <BehaviorTree ID="Test2">
        <Sequence name="main_sequence">
            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="driveposition" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="search1" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="search2" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="search3" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="carryarea1" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="driveposition" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>

    <BehaviorTree ID="Test3">
        <Sequence name="main_sequence">

            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>

            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree> 

    <BehaviorTree ID="TestNav">
        <Sequence name="main_sequence">
            <MoveGripper action="open"/>
            <NavigateVehicle/>
            <Sequence name="main_manipulator_sequence">
                <Fallback name="find_object">
                    <ForceFailure name="force_failure11">
                        <Sequence name="search1">
                            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="search1" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                        </Sequence>
                    </ForceFailure>
                    <Sequence name="search_frame3">
                        <Sequence name="search2">
                            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="search2" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                        </Sequence>
                        <ObjectSearch object_pose="{object_pose}"/>
                    </Sequence>
                    <ForceFailure name="force_failure1">
                        <Sequence name="gotodrive">
                            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="driveposition" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                        </Sequence>
                    </ForceFailure>
                </Fallback>
                <Sequence name="handle_object">
                    <Fallback name="handle_not_able_to_close">
                        <Sequence name="pick_object">
                            <Sequence name="main_move_to_object">
                                <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="object" object_pose="{object_pose}" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                                <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                            </Sequence>
                            <MoveGripper action="close"/>

                        <ForceFailure name="force_failure1">
                            <Sequence name="movetodrive">
                                <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="driveposition" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                                <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                            </Sequence>
                        </ForceFailure>
                    </Fallback>
                    <Sequence name="leave_object">
                        <Fallback name="find_empty_frame">
                            <Fallback name="check_empty_frame">
                                <EmptyFrame check_frame="carryarea1" empty_frame="{empty_frame}"/>
                                <EmptyFrame check_frame="carryarea2" empty_frame="{empty_frame}"/>
                                <EmptyFrame check_frame="carryarea3" empty_frame="{empty_frame}"/>
                            </Fallback>
                            <ForceFailure name="force_failure2">
                                <MoveGripper action="open"/>
                            </ForceFailure>
                        </Fallback>
                        <Sequence name="emptyframe">
                            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="{empty_frame}" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                        </Sequence>
                        <MoveGripper action="open"/>
                        <Sequence name="drive">
                            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="driveposition" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                        </Sequence>
                    </Sequence>
                </Sequence>
            </Sequence>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree> 

    <BehaviorTree ID="TestTree">
        <Sequence name="main_sequence">
            <MoveGripper action="open"/>
            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="search1" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>

            <Fallback name="object_search">

                        <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>

                </ForceFailure>
            </Fallback>
            <Sequence name="handle_object">
                <Fallback name="handle_not_able_to_close">
                    <Sequence name="pick_object">
                        <Sequence name="main_move_to_object">
                            <PlanManipulatorPath plan_to_frame="object" object_pose="{object_pose}" manipulator_path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>

                            <MoveManipulator path="{manipulator_path}" move_to_frame="{move_to_frame}"/>
                        </Sequence>
                    </ForceFailure>
                </Fallback>
                <Sequence name="leave_object">
                    <Fallback name="find_empty_frame">
                        <Fallback name="check_empty_frame">
                            <EmptyFrame check_frame="carryarea1" empty_frame="{empty_frame}"/>
                            <EmptyFrame check_frame="carryarea2" empty_frame="{empty_frame}"/>
                            <EmptyFrame check_frame="carryarea3" empty_frame="{empty_frame}"/>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree orchestrates the process of generating grasping candidates for a robot. It begins by segmenting the tabletop from the scene, attempting this operation up to three times if unsuccessful. Following this, it checks if the desired object is present on the blackboard and extracts its point cloud if available; otherwise, it proceeds with tabletop clustering. Finally, it generates grasping candidates based on the extracted object cloud and table height. The behavior tree ensures that the robot can effectively identify and generate viable grasping options for objects in its environment.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="GPDGraspGeneration">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="GPDGraspGeneration">
        <Sequence>
            <RetryUntilSuccesful num_attempts="3">
                <TableTopSegmentation original_cloud="{original_cloud}" image_scene="{image_scene}" table_height="{table_height}" original_cloud_transformed="{original_cloud_transformed}" tabletop_cloud="{tabletop_cloud}" plane_cloud="{plane_cloud}" nonplane_cloud="{nonplane_cloud}"/>
            </RetryUntilSuccesful>
            <ConditionalSequence condition="False">
                <Decorator entry="{desired_object}" ID="BlackboardEntryCheck" name="DesiredObjectEntryCheck">
                    <ObjectCloudExtraction original_cloud="{original_cloud}" image_scene="{image_scene}" object_cloud="{object_cloud}" tabletop_cloud="{tabletop_cloud}" desired_object="{desired_object}"/>
                </Decorator>
                <TableTopClustering object_cloud="{object_cloud}" tabletop_cloud="{tabletop_cloud}"/>
            </ConditionalSequence>
            <GenerateGraspingCandidates object_cloud="{object_cloud}" table_height="{table_height}" grasp_candidates="{grasp_candidates}" original_cloud_transformed="{original_cloud_transformed}"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Decorator ID="BlackboardEntryCheck">
            <input_port name="entry"/>
        </Decorator>
        <Condition ID="foo"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree outlines a simple task for a robot to follow a path to a specified goal. It first computes a path to the given goal using a "GridBased" planner, and then instructs the robot to follow the computed path using a "FollowPath" controller. This behavior tree is focused on guiding the robot through a predefined path to reach its designated goal.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <Sequence>
      <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
      <FollowPath path="{path}"  controller_id="FollowPath"/>
    </Sequence>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree outlines a series of actions and conditions for controlling a robot or an autonomous system. The main sequence involves the robot waiting for a specified duration, then repeatedly moving to a specific goal position. This movement is repeated 10 times before another wait action is executed.

Additionally, the behavior tree includes various utility nodes such as logging messages, performing mathematical operations, subscribing to ROS topics, and interacting with Actionlib action servers. These utility nodes enable the robot to handle diverse tasks such as fire detection, extinguishing fires, window detection, takeoff, landing, and more.

The tree also incorporates decorators and control nodes like ForceSuccess, OnlyOnce, Interruptible, Loop, WhileSuccess, and Cooldown, which modify the behavior of child nodes within the tree.

Overall, the behavior tree orchestrates the robot's actions, decision-making, and interactions with its environment in a structured and repeatable manner, enabling it to perform complex tasks autonomously.

<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">

    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">

            <ForceSuccess>
                <Repeat num_cycles="10">
                    <Action name="Stage1GoToGoal" ID="UPOGoToGoalByName" goal_name="stage_1_pos_final_5" action="/Make_Plan" state="gpf5"/>
                </Repeat>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <Action ID="WaitSeconds" duration="3"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree outlines the decision-making process for an animal, with different actions based on various conditions. The "MainTree" initially attempts a random big move as its fallback action. The "ShedTree" encompasses multiple scenarios: if the animal is on pasture during the day and in the shed, it will leave the shed, find a random pasture field, and move there. If it's on pasture at night but not in the shed, it will find the shed, move towards it, and enter. During the day, if not in the shed, it will make a random move.

The conditions include checking the animal's life stage, gender, hunger, location, and other attributes to determine the appropriate action. Actions range from finding prey, giving birth, laying eggs, moving, sleeping, and attempting reproduction. The tree also includes sub-trees for specific behaviors related to being in or leaving the shed.

Overall, the tree models the complex decision-making process of an animal, considering its environment
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
    <!--  ===================================  -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <FallbackStar name="AnimalStandard">
            <Action ID="RandomMoveBig"/>
        </FallbackStar>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!--  ===================================  -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="ShedTree">
        <FallbackStar>
            <SequenceStar>
                <Condition ID="IsOnPasture"/>
                <Condition ID="IsDay"/>
                <Condition ID="IsInShed"/>
                <Action ID="LeaveShed"/>
                <Action ID="FindRandomPastureField"/>
                <Action ID="Move"/>
            </SequenceStar>
            <SequenceStar>
                <Condition ID="IsOnPasture"/>
                <Condition ID="IsNight"/>
                <Inverter>
                    <Condition ID="IsInShed"/>
                </Inverter>
                <Action ID="FindShed"/>
                <Action ID="Move"/>
                <Action ID="EnterShed"/>
            </SequenceStar>
            <SequenceStar>
                <Condition ID="IsDay"/>
                <Inverter>
                    <Condition ID="IsInShed"/>
                </Inverter>
                <Action ID="RandomMove"/>
            </SequenceStar>
        </FallbackStar>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!--  ===================================  -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Condition ID="CanHaveSex"/>
        <Action ID="EatPrey"/>
        <Action ID="EnterShed"/>
        <Action ID="FindPrey"/>
        <Action ID="FindRandomPastureField"/>
        <Action ID="FindRetreat"/>
        <Action ID="FindShed"/>
        <Action ID="GiveBirth"/>
        <Condition ID="IsAdult"/>
        <Condition ID="IsCarnivore"/>
        <Condition ID="IsDay"/>
        <Condition ID="IsEgg"/>
        <Condition ID="IsEggLayer"/>
        <Condition ID="IsFemale"/>
        <Condition ID="IsHerbivore"/>
        <Condition ID="IsHungry"/>
        <Condition ID="IsInShed"/>
        <Condition ID="IsMale"/>
        <Condition ID="IsNight"/>
        <Condition ID="IsOnPasture"/>
        <Condition ID="IsPregnant"/>
        <Condition ID="IsProducer"/>
        <Condition ID="IsReadyToGiveBirth"/>
        <Condition ID="IsWoodVermin"/>
        <Condition ID="IsYoung"/>
        <Action ID="KillPrey"/>
        <Action ID="LayEgg"/>
        <Action ID="LeaveShed"/>
        <Action ID="Move"/>
        <Action ID="Produce"/>
        <Action ID="RandomMove"/>
        <Action ID="RandomMoveBig"/>
        <SubTree ID="ShedTree"/>
        <Action ID="Sleep"/>
        <Action ID="TryHaveSex"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!--  ===================================  -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree outlines the decision-making process for an animal in a simulated environment. The tree's structure is based on various conditions and actions that the animal can perform.

The tree begins with a FallbackStar node, which contains three SequenceStar nodes. Each SequenceStar represents a set of conditions and actions to be executed based on the state of the environment and the animal itself.

The first SequenceStar deals with the animal's movement during the day, either leaving the shed and finding a random pasture field or moving if it's already on the pasture.

The second SequenceStar handles the animal's behavior at night, focusing on finding shelter if not in the shed and entering it, or continuing to move if already on the pasture.

The third SequenceStar addresses daytime activities when not in the shed, involving random movement.

The TreeNodesModel provides a list of all possible conditions and actions that the animal can evaluate and execute within the behavior tree, such as eating prey, laying eggs, and finding retreats.

In
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
    <!--  ===================================  -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <FallbackStar>
            <SequenceStar>
                <Condition ID="IsOnPasture"/>
                <Condition ID="IsDay"/>
                <Condition ID="IsInShed"/>
                <Action ID="LeaveShed"/>
                <Action ID="FindRandomPastureField"/>
                <Action ID="Move"/>
            </SequenceStar>
            <SequenceStar>
                <Condition ID="IsOnPasture"/>
                <Condition ID="IsNight"/>
                <Inverter>
                    <Condition ID="IsInShed"/>
                </Inverter>
                <Action ID="FindShed"/>
                <Action ID="Move"/>
                <Action ID="EnterShed"/>
            </SequenceStar>
            <SequenceStar>
                <Condition ID="IsDay"/>
                <Inverter>
                    <Condition ID="IsInShed"/>
                </Inverter>
                <Action ID="RandomMove"/>
            </SequenceStar>
        </FallbackStar>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!--  ===================================  -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Condition ID="CanHaveSex"/>
        <Action ID="EatPrey"/>
        <Action ID="EnterShed"/>
        <Action ID="FindPrey"/>
        <Action ID="FindRandomPastureField"/>
        <Action ID="FindRetreat"/>
        <Action ID="FindShed"/>
        <Action ID="GiveBirth"/>
        <Condition ID="IsAdult"/>
        <Condition ID="IsCarnivore"/>
        <Condition ID="IsDay"/>
        <Condition ID="IsEgg"/>
        <Condition ID="IsEggLayer"/>
        <Condition ID="IsFemale"/>
        <Condition ID="IsHerbivore"/>
        <Condition ID="IsHungry"/>
        <Condition ID="IsInShed"/>
        <Condition ID="IsMale"/>
        <Condition ID="IsNight"/>
        <Condition ID="IsOnPasture"/>
        <Condition ID="IsPregnant"/>
        <Condition ID="IsProducer"/>
        <Condition ID="IsReadyToGiveBirth"/>
        <Condition ID="IsWoodVermin"/>
        <Condition ID="IsYoung"/>
        <Action ID="KillPrey"/>
        <Action ID="LayEgg"/>
        <Action ID="LeaveShed"/>
        <Action ID="Move"/>
        <Action ID="Produce"/>
        <Action ID="RandomMove"/>
        <Action ID="Sleep"/>
        <Action ID="TryHaveSex"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!--  ===================================  -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates a robot's navigation and interaction with humans. The robot is tasked to clear the global cost map, seek multiple predefined search poses, and then continuously navigate to each pose until a failure occurs. Upon reaching each pose, it communicates a speech message associated with the goal, moves towards the next goal using the "MoveRobot" subtree, and speaks the goal speech. 

Additionally, the robot employs a decision-making process when encountering humans. It first attempts to detect a person and if successful, it communicates "Hi there! I found you!". If no person is detected, it performs a spin action and says "I didn't see anyone.".

Overall, the behavior tree coordinates the robot's autonomous navigation to predetermined locations, human interaction through speech communication, and adaptive responses based on detecting human presence.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
	<BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
		<Sequence>
			<Nav2ClearGlobalCostMap />
			<!-- RobotSeekInitAction
				search_poses="-4.3,-4,180.0;-4.7,-6.6,270.0;-6.0,-4.2,206.0" /--->
      <!-- RobotSeekInitAction
        search_poses="-4.3,-4,180.0;0.75,-3.7,206.0;0.71,-6.0,206.0;-4.7,-6.6,270.0;-6.0,-4.2,206.0;-6.4,-1.9,0.0;-8.0,1.5,90.0;-4.4,0.95,218.0" /-->
      <RobotSeekInitAction
        search_poses="-4.3,-4,180.0;-4.7,-6.6,270.0;-6.0,-4.2,206.0;-6.4,-1.9,0.0;-8.0,1.5,90.0;-4.4,0.95,218.0" />

			<KeepRunningUntilFailure>
				<Sequence>
					<RobotSeekNextSearchPose next_goal="{next_goal}" goal_speech="{goal_speech}" />
					<SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="next_goal" />
					<TextToSpeechActionClient msg="{goal_speech}" />
					<Sequence>
             <Fallback>
               <Sequence>
								<ReactiveSequence>
									<Inverter>
										<HumanPoseDetect pose_lr_check="presence" expected_pose_left="" expected_pose_right=""
											detected_person="{detected_person}" pose_left_speech="{pose_left_speech}"
											pose_right_speech="{pose_right_speech}" />
									</Inverter>
									<RobotSpin angle="340" velocity="0.5" />
								</ReactiveSequence>
								<Sequence>
                   <TextToSpeechActionClient msg="I didn't see anyone." />
								</Sequence>
							</Sequence>
							<Sequence>
								<HumanPoseDetect pose_lr_check="presence" expected_pose_left="" expected_pose_right=""
									detected_person="{detected_person}" pose_left_speech="{pose_left_speech}"
									pose_right_speech="{pose_right_speech}" />
								<TextToSpeechActionClient msg="Hi there! I found you!" />
							</Sequence>
						</Fallback>
					</Sequence>
				</Sequence>
			</KeepRunningUntilFailure>
		</Sequence>
	</BehaviorTree>

	<BehaviorTree ID="MoveRobot">
		<Sequence name="SetGoal">
			<Nav2Client goal="{target}" />
		</Sequence>
	</BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree is designed for a robot to continuously listen for a wake word. Once the wake word is detected, it will perform a sequence of actions: tilt its head by 10 degrees and then speak "Hey there." The tree structure ensures that the robot keeps running these actions until a failure occurs, allowing it to constantly respond to the wake word. This behavior enables the robot to engage in an interactive conversation or respond to specific commands upon detecting the wake word.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
	<BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
		<KeepRunningUntilFailure>
			<ForceSuccess>
				<Sequence>
					<WakeWordDetected since_sec="3.0" />
					<HeadTiltAction angle="10" dwell_ms="1500" />
					<TextToSpeechActionClient msg="Hey there." />
				</Sequence>
			</ForceSuccess>
		</KeepRunningUntilFailure>
	</BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed for a robot to manage its energy levels and navigate to specific locations. It first checks if the battery level is low and not charging, then it attempts to go to a charging station. If that fails or the conditions are not met, it waits. If the battery is charged or charging, it proceeds to check if it has reached its destination and navigates accordingly.

Overall, the behavior tree orchestrates the robot's actions based on reactive decision-making, ensuring it prioritizes energy management and navigation tasks. The tree employs YARP (Yet Another Robot Platform) conditions and actions to interact with the robot's skills and ports, allowing it to make informed decisions and execute appropriate actions in real-time.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<!--
 Copyright (C) 2020 Fondazione Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia (IIT)
 All Rights Reserved.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <ReactiveSequence>
            <ReactiveFallback>
                <ReactiveSequence>
<!--                     <Condition ID="YARPCondition" name="BatteryLevel" port_name="BatteryLevelSkill" carrier="tcp" /> -->
                    <Condition ID="YARPCondition" name="BatteryLevel" port_name="BatteryLevelSkill" carrier="tcp+send.portmonitor2+file.Skill_request+type.dll" />
<!--                    <Condition ID="YARPCondition" name="BatteryLevel" port_name="BatteryLevelSkill" carrier="tcp+send.portmonitor2+recv.portmonitor2+file.Skill_request+type.dll" />-->
                    <Condition ID="YARPCondition" name="BatteryNotCharging" port_name="BatteryNotChargingSkill"/>
                </ReactiveSequence>
                <ReactiveSequence>
                  <ReactiveFallback>
                      <Condition ID="YARPCondition" name="IsAtChargingStation" port_name=""/>
                       <Action ID="YARPAction" name="GoToChargingStation" carrier="tcp+send.portmonitor2+file.Skill_request+type.dll"/>
                  </ReactiveFallback>
                    <Action ID="AlwaysRunning" name="Wait"/>
                </ReactiveSequence>
            </ReactiveFallback>
            <ReactiveFallback>
                <Condition ID="YARPCondition" name="IsAtDestination" port_name=""/>
                 <Action ID="YARPAction" name="GoToDestination" port_name="goTo" carrier="tcp+send.portmonitor2+file.Skill_request+type.dll"/>
            </ReactiveFallback>
        </ReactiveSequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="AlwaysRunning"/>
        <Condition ID="FlipFlopCondition"/>
        <Action ID="YARPAction">
            <input_port name="port_name" type="std::string"/>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="YARPCondition"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree is designed for a robot to navigate through a series of waypoints using the NavigateToPose behavior. It follows a reactive fallback approach, where it continuously attempts to achieve the next goal until all goals are achieved or a failure occurs. The process involves getting the next goal, navigating to the pose, loading a pallet at the goal location, and then marking the goal as achieved in the blackboard. This cycle continues until all goals are completed or an error arises. Overall, the behavior tree orchestrates the robot's movement and task execution, ensuring that it efficiently navigates through the given waypoints while handling any potential interruptions or failures.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree processes each of the given waypoints with NavigateToPose.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <ReactiveFallback name="FollowTargets">
      <AllGoalsAchieved goal_achieved="{goal_achieved}"/>
      <KeepRunningUntilFailure>
        <ReactiveSequence>
          <GetNextGoal goals="{goals}" goal="{goal}" goal_achieved="{goal_achieved}"/>
          <NavigateToPose goal="{goal}"/>
          <LoadPallet goal="{goal}"/>
          <SetBlackboard output_key="goal_achieved" value="true"/>
        </ReactiveSequence>
      </KeepRunningUntilFailure>
    </ReactiveFallback>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates the movement of a robot to three different goals, Goal_a, Goal_b, and Goal_c. The robot is initially directed to move to Goal_a, followed by Goal_b, with each movement being separated by a waiting period. This sequence is set to repeat indefinitely until interrupted by the "gohome" event. Upon interruption or completion of the repeated sequence, the robot will then proceed to Goal_c.

The MoveRobot behavior tree defines the sequence for setting the goal and instructing the robot to move to the specified target location.

In summary, the behavior tree outlines a repetitive task for the robot to navigate between multiple goals, incorporating waiting periods and the ability to interrupt the sequence to return home.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute = "MainTree">
    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <Sequence>
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_a" value="1.17;-1.65;0.0;1.0" />
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_b" value="1.1;1.51;0.0;1.0" />
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_c" value="-1.25;0.324;0.0;1.0" />
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Waiting_time" value="2"/>
            <Fallback>
                <ReactiveSequence>
                    <InterruptEvent event="gohome"/>
                    <Repeat num_cycles="-1">
                        <Sequence>
                            <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_a" />
                            <WaitingEvent name="waiting_event" waiting_time="{Waiting_time}"/>
                            <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_b" />
                            <WaitingEvent name="waiting_event" waiting_time="{Waiting_time}"/>
                        </Sequence>
                    </Repeat>
                </ReactiveSequence>
                <Sequence>
                    <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_c" />
                </Sequence>
            </Fallback>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>

    <BehaviorTree ID="MoveRobot">
        <Sequence name="SetGoal">
            <MoveBase goal="{target}" />
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates the movement of three robots towards specific goals. Each robot is assigned a set of goals (Goal_a, Goal_b, Goal_c) and a backup goal (Goal_backup). The robots operate in parallel, attempting to reach their respective goals while allowing for retries upon failure.

The sequence begins with setting the goals and assigning each robot a unique identifier. Then, a retry mechanism is employed to ensure that the robots persistently attempt to achieve their goals, even if they initially fail. 

Each robot follows a pattern where it repeatedly attempts to reach its designated goals in a specific order. If unsuccessful, it falls back to the backup goal. This process continues indefinitely until the goals are reached or the maximum number of attempts is exhausted.

Overall, the behavior tree coordinates the concurrent movement of multiple robots towards their individual goals, ensuring resilience through retries and fallback mechanisms.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute = "MainTree" >
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <Sequence>
      <!-- Set goal -->
      <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_a" value="-6.432;3.35;0.000" />
      <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_b" value="-0.95;0.6;0.0" />
      <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_c" value="-1.488;3.7;0.00" />
      <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_backup" value="-1.0;1.0;0.00" />

      <!-- Set joined robot name -->
      <SetBlackboard output_key="robot1" value="" />
      <SetBlackboard output_key="robot2" value="nb2_1" />
      <SetBlackboard output_key="robot3" value="nb2_2" />

      <RetryUntilSuccesful num_attempts="3">  <!-- Retry once fail -->
        <Parallel threshold="3">    <!-- threshold = number of robot -->
          
          <!-- robot1 -->
          <Repeat num_cycles="-1">    <!-- repeat infinitely -->
            <RetryUntilSuccesful num_attempts="3">
              <Fallback>    <!-- set goal to Goal_backup once the Sequence below fails -->
                <Sequence>
                  <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot1" target="Goal_a" />
                  <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot1" target="Goal_b" />
                  <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot1" target="Goal_c" />
                </Sequence>
                <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot1" target="Goal_backup" />
              </Fallback>
            </RetryUntilSuccesful>
          </Repeat>
          
          <!-- robot2 -->
          <Repeat num_cycles="-1">
            <RetryUntilSuccesful num_attempts="3">
              <Fallback>
                <Sequence>
                  <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot2" target="Goal_b" />
                  <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot2" target="Goal_c" />
                  <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot2" target="Goal_a" />
                </Sequence>
                <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot2" target="Goal_backup" />
              </Fallback>
            </RetryUntilSuccesful>
          </Repeat>
          
          <!-- robot3 -->
          <Repeat num_cycles="-1">
            <RetryUntilSuccesful num_attempts="3">
              <Fallback>
                <Sequence>
                  <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot3" target="Goal_c" />
                  <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot3" target="Goal_a" />
                  <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot3" target="Goal_b" />
                </Sequence>
                <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" robot_num="robot3" target="Goal_backup" />
              </Fallback>
            </RetryUntilSuccesful>
          </Repeat>

        </Parallel>
      </RetryUntilSuccesful>
    </Sequence>
  </BehaviorTree>


  <BehaviorTree ID="MoveRobot">
    <Sequence name="SetGoal">
      <MoveBase robot="{robot_num}" goal="{target}" />
    </Sequence>
  </BehaviorTree>

</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree represents a robot's navigation system. It attempts to navigate to a specified location by computing a path and then following it. If the navigation fails, it will retry up to 7 times. In case of repeated failures, it will attempt recovery by clearing the local and global costmaps and then spinning in place to reassess the environment before retrying the navigation. This behavior tree is designed to ensure robust navigation even in challenging or dynamic environments.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
    <RetryUntilSuccesful name="retry_navigate" num_attempts="7">
      <FallbackStar>
        <SequenceStar name="navigate">
          <ComputePathToPose endpoints="${endpoints}" path="${path}"/>
	  <FollowPath path="${path}"/>
        </SequenceStar>
        <ForceFailure>
          <SequenceStar name="recovery">
            <clearEntirelyCostmapServiceRequest service_name="/local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
            <clearEntirelyCostmapServiceRequest service_name="/global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
            <Spin/>
          </SequenceStar>
        </ForceFailure>
      </FallbackStar>
    </RetryUntilSuccesful>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree is designed for a robot to navigate with periodic global path replanning at 1 Hz and includes recovery actions. The main sequence "NavigateWithReplanning" utilizes a rate controller to ensure the frequency of path planning, followed by executing the path using "FollowPath". If the robot encounters difficulties or failures, it will attempt recovery actions such as clearing the local and global costmaps and performing a spin maneuver. Additionally, the tree allows for up to 6 retries before considering the navigation task as failed. This behavior tree ensures that the robot can continuously navigate its environment while handling potential obstacles or disruptions through periodic replanning and recovery mechanisms.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz and it also has
  recovery actions.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="6">
      <Sequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
        <RateController hz="1.0">
          <Fallback>
            <GoalReached/>
             <ComputePathToPose goal="${goal}" path="${path}"/>
          </Fallback>
        </RateController>
        <FollowPath path="${path}"/>
      </Sequence>
      <SequenceStar name="RecoveryActions">
        <clearEntirelyCostmapServiceRequest service_name="/local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
        <clearEntirelyCostmapServiceRequest service_name="/global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
        <Spin/>
      </SequenceStar>
    </RecoveryNode>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates a robot's path planning and execution. It first computes a path using the global planner, then runs two sub-branches in parallel. The first sub-branch involves executing the local planner to follow the computed path, while the second sub-branch controls the rate at which new paths are computed by the global planner and updates the path for the local planner. The goal for the global planner and the resulting path are stored in the blackboard.

The behavior tree ensures that the path computation and execution happen concurrently, with the ability to control the frequency of path computations through the "hz" parameter. The ParallelNode returns the result of the FollowPath operation, and the ComputePathToPose operation is continuously invoked at a controlled rate.

In summary, this behavior tree manages the continuous path planning and execution for the robot, ensuring that it can adapt to changing environments and goals in real-time.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree first computes a path using the global planner (ComputePathToPose).
  Then, it runs two sub-branches in parallel. The first sub-branch is a FollowPath
  operation (the local planner). In parallel, there is a rate controlled execution of
  FollowPath (the global planner). Each time a new path is computed, the path update
  is sent to the local planner. The right branch, which is the rate controlled
  ComputePathToPose, always returns RUNNING. Because the Parallel node uses a
  threshold of 1, whenever the FollowPath returns SUCCESS or FAILURE, the parallel
  node will return this result.

  The goal (input to the global planner) and the resulting path (output of the global
  planner and input to the local planner) are passed on the blackboard.

  The rate at which the ComputePathToPose operation is invoked can be controlled with
  the hz parameter to the RateController node.
-->

<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <SequenceStar name="root">
      <ComputePathToPose goal="${goal}" path="${path}"/>
      <ParallelNode threshold="1">
        <FollowPath path="${path}"/>
        <Sequence>
          <RateController hz="1.0">
            <ComputePathToPose goal="${goal}" path="${path}"/>
          </RateController>
          <UpdatePath/>
        </Sequence>
      </ParallelNode>
    </SequenceStar>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates the actions of a robot. Initially, it checks if the battery component requires attention. If so, it triggers a sequence to conserve energy by reconfiguring and navigating to a recharge station for recharging.

If the battery is not an issue, the robot switches to normal mode and starts patrolling by navigating through multiple waypoints in a sequence. The patrolling sequence utilizes a "SequenceStar" node, allowing the robot to navigate through different waypoints efficiently.

The tree's structure ensures that the robot prioritizes recharging when necessary and then transitions to its routine patrolling behavior when the battery is functioning optimally. This behavior tree effectively manages the robot's energy needs while ensuring consistent coverage of its designated area through waypoint navigation.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <Sequence>
            <Fallback>
                <Action ID="CheckComponent" component="battery"/>
                <Sequence name="recharging">
                    <Action ID="Reconfigure" mode="f_energy_saving_mode"/>
                    <Action ID="NavigateToWp" goal="recharge_station" name="navigate_to_wp"/>
                    <Action ID="Recharge"/>
                </Sequence>
            </Fallback>
            <Sequence name="">
                <Action ID="Reconfigure" mode="f_normal_mode"/>
                <SequenceStar name="patrolling">
                    <Action ID="NavigateToWp" goal="wp_1" name="navigate_to_wp"/>
                    <Action ID="NavigateToWp" goal="wp_2" name="navigate_to_wp"/>
                    <Action ID="NavigateToWp" goal="wp_3" name="navigate_to_wp"/>
                    <Action ID="NavigateToWp" goal="wp_4" name="navigate_to_wp"/>
                    <Action ID="NavigateToWp" goal="wp_5" name="navigate_to_wp"/>
                    <Action ID="NavigateToWp" goal="wp_6" name="navigate_to_wp"/>
                    <Action ID="NavigateToWp" goal="wp_7" name="navigate_to_wp"/>
                </SequenceStar>
            </Sequence>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="CheckComponent">
            <input_port name="component"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="NavigateToWp">
            <input_port name="goal"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="Recharge"/>
        <Action ID="Reconfigure">
            <input_port name="mode"/>
        </Action>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed for a robotic system to execute a series of actions based on certain conditions and inputs. The tree consists of a main sequence that repeats a specified number of times, with each repetition containing multiple sub-actions.

The main sequence includes:
1. A fallback node that checks and performs actions based on certain conditions related to the robot's state and desired sequence.
2. A reactive sequence that handles different action types such as moving, staying, guiding, or transitioning, based on the current action type and robot's state.
3. An update action that modifies the action sequence and executed sequence based on the current action type and desired sequence.

The tree also includes various action nodes such as locomotion start, pick action, recovery stand, replanning requests, and more, each with specific input and output ports for communication with other nodes.

Overall, the behavior tree orchestrates the robot's behavior by repeating sequences of actions while reacting to its environment and updating its internal state based on the performed actions and
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Repeat num_cycles="{num_cycles}">
            <Sequence>
                <Fallback>
                    <Condition ID="LTLPreCheck" ltl_state_current="{ltl_state_current}" ltl_state_desired_sequence="{ltl_state_desired_sequence}" ltl_state_executed_sequence="{ltl_state_executed_sequence}"/>
                    <ForceFailure>
                        <Action ID="ReplanningRequestLevel2" ltl_state_current="{ltl_state_current}" ltl_state_executed_sequence="{ltl_state_executed_sequence}" replanning_request="{replanning_request}"/>
                    </ForceFailure>
                </Fallback>
                <ReactiveSequence>
                    <Fallback>
                        <Condition ID="ReactiveLTLStateCheck" ltl_state_current="{ltl_state_current}" ltl_state_desired_sequence="{ltl_state_desired_sequence}"/>
                        <ForceFailure>
                            <Action ID="ReplanningRequestLevel2" ltl_state_current="{ltl_state_current}" ltl_state_executed_sequence="{ltl_state_executed_sequence}" replanning_request="{replanning_request}"/>
                        </ForceFailure>
                    </Fallback>
                    <Fallback>
                        <Switch4 case_1="move" case_2="stay" case_3="start_training" case_4="terminate_training" variable="{bt_action_type}">
                            <Action ID="MoveAction" bt_action_type="{bt_action_type}" current_action="{current_action}" goal_sent="{goal_sent}" move_base_finished="{move_base_finished}" move_base_idle="{move_base_idle}"/>
                            <Action ID="StayAction" bt_action_type="{bt_action_type}" current_action="{current_action}" ltl_state_current="{ltl_state_current}"/>
                            <Action ID="GuideAction" bt_action_type="{bt_action_type}" current_action="{current_action}" ltl_state_current="{ltl_state_current}"/>
                            <Action ID="BackNormalAction" bt_action_type="{bt_action_type}" current_action="{current_action}" ltl_state_current="{ltl_state_current}"/>
                            <AlwaysFailure/>
                        </Switch4>
                        <ForceFailure>
                            <Action ID="ReplanningRequestLevel3" ltl_state_current="{ltl_state_current}" ltl_state_executed_sequence="{ltl_state_executed_sequence}" replanning_request="{replanning_request}"/>
                        </ForceFailure>
                    </Fallback>
                </ReactiveSequence>
                <Action ID="UpdateLTL" action_sequence="{action_sequence}" action_sequence_executed="{action_sequence_executed}" bt_action_type="{bt_action_type}" current_action="{current_action}" ltl_state_desired_sequence="{ltl_state_desired_sequence}"/>
            </Sequence>
        </Repeat>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="BackNormalAction">
            <input_port name="bt_action_type"/>
            <input_port name="current_action"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="DropAction">
            <input_port name="bt_action_type"/>
            <input_port name="current_action"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="GuideAction">
            <input_port name="bt_action_type"/>
            <input_port name="current_action"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="LTLPreCheck">
            <input_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
            <input_port name="ltl_state_desired_sequence"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_executed_sequence"/>
        </Condition>
        <Action ID="LocomotionStart">
            <input_port name="locomotion_status"/>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="LocomotionStatusCheck">
            <input_port name="locomotion_status"/>
        </Condition>
        <Action ID="MoveAction">
            <input_port name="bt_action_type"/>
            <input_port name="current_action"/>
            <output_port name="goal_sent"/>
            <input_port name="move_base_finished"/>
            <input_port name="move_base_idle"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="PickAction">
            <input_port name="bt_action_type"/>
            <input_port name="current_action"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="ReactiveLTLStateCheck">
            <input_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
            <input_port name="ltl_state_desired_sequence"/>
        </Condition>
        <Action ID="RecoveryStand">
            <input_port name="locomotion_status"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ReplanningRequestLevel1">
            <input_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_executed_sequence"/>
            <inout_port name="replanning_request"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ReplanningRequestLevel2">
            <input_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_executed_sequence"/>
            <inout_port name="replanning_request"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ReplanningRequestLevel3">
            <input_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_executed_sequence"/>
            <inout_port name="replanning_request"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="StayAction">
            <input_port name="bt_action_type"/>
            <input_port name="current_action"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="SynchronizedTransitionAction">
            <input_port name="bt_action_type"/>
            <input_port name="current_action"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_current"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="UpdateLTL">
            <inout_port name="action_sequence"/>
            <inout_port name="action_sequence_executed"/>
            <output_port name="bt_action_type"/>
            <output_port name="current_action"/>
            <inout_port name="ltl_state_desired_sequence"/>
        </Action>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree outlines a navigation system for a robot. It uses a pipeline sequence to guide the robot through a series of steps. First, it employs a distance controller to compute a path to a specified goal using a grid-based planner. Once the path is computed, the robot follows this path using a designated path-following controller. This behavior tree essentially orchestrates the process of navigating the robot to a specific location while allowing for replanning if necessary.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
      <DistanceController distance="0.1">
        <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
      </DistanceController>
      <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>
    </PipelineSequence>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree represents a robot's navigation system that periodically updates its global path at a frequency of 1 Hz. The robot uses a pipeline sequence to control its speed and compute the path to a specific goal using the "GridBased" planner. Once the path is computed, the robot follows it using a specified controller. The speed controller ensures that the robot's speed stays within defined limits while following the path. This behavior tree essentially orchestrates the process of navigating towards a goal with periodic replanning to ensure efficient and safe movement.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz.
-->

<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
      <SpeedController min_rate="0.1" max_rate="1.0" min_speed="0.0" max_speed="0.26" filter_duration="0.3">
        <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
      </SpeedController>
      <FollowPath path="{path}"  controller_id="FollowPath"/>
    </PipelineSequence>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree is designed for a robot to navigate while periodically replanning its global path at a frequency of 1 Hz. It uses a pipeline sequence where the first step involves computing the path to a specific goal using a planner called "GridBased" and storing the computed path. The second step involves the robot following the computed path using a controller identified as "FollowPath". This process repeats continuously, ensuring that the robot dynamically adjusts its path based on changing environmental conditions or new obstacles.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz.
-->

<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">

        <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed for a robot to navigate through an environment with periodic global path replanning at 1 Hz and includes recovery actions. The robot will attempt navigation recovery up to 6 times.

The main sequence involves navigating with replanning, which includes computing the path to a specific goal using a grid-based planner and clearing the entire global costmap context. It also involves following the computed path and clearing the local costmap context.

In case of failure, the recovery fallback mechanism is triggered. This includes reacting to updated goals, executing a series of recovery actions such as clearing the local and global costmaps, spinning, and waiting before attempting navigation again.

Overall, the behavior tree ensures that the robot can continuously navigate its environment by periodically updating its global path and recovering from any navigation failures.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz and it also has
  recovery actions.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="6" name="NavigateRecovery">
      <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
        <RateController hz="1.0">
          <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="ComputePathToPose">
            <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
          </RecoveryNode>
        </RateController>
        <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="FollowPath">
          <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>
          <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
        </RecoveryNode>
      </PipelineSequence>
      <ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
        <GoalUpdated/>
        <SequenceStar name="RecoveryActions">
          <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
          <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
          <Spin spin_dist="1.57"/>
          <Wait wait_duration="5"/>
        </SequenceStar>
      </ReactiveFallback>
    </RecoveryNode>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates a robotic pick-and-place operation. It begins by selecting an object to pick, retrieving its pose, and then initiating parallel processes to track the object's pose and approach it. After a 3-second wait period, the object's pose is retrieved again, followed by another parallel process to track the pose and execute the pick action on the specified object.

In summary, the robot first identifies an object to pick, tracks and approaches its location in parallel, waits for a specified duration, re-evaluates the object's pose, and then executes the pick action on the object.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute = "MainTree" >
    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
       <Sequence name="pick">
            <SelectPick  name="select_pick"/>
            <GetPickObject  name="get_pick_object" object_id="{object_id}"/>
            <GetPoseFromObject  name="get_pose_from_object" object_id="{object_id}" wp_pose="{pose}"/>
            <Parallel success_threshold="1" failure_threshold="1">
                <Track name="pick" pose="{pose}" />
                <ApproachObject name="approach_object" object_pose="{pose}"/>
            </Parallel>
            <Wait seconds="3"/>
            <GetPoseFromObject  name="get_pose_from_object" object_id="{object_id}" wp_pose="{pose}"/>
            <Parallel success_threshold="1" failure_threshold="1">
                <Track name="pick" pose="{pose}" />
                <Pick name="pick" object_id="{object_id}" object_pose="{pose}"/>
            </Parallel>
       </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.

The behavior tree outlines a sequence of actions for a robotic arm. It starts by retrieving the joint positions for a specific pose called "UPTRAY" and then sets the left and right arm joints to these positions. This process is repeated for poses "EXTENDED", "GRIPPING", and "REST".

            <SetArmJointsRight joints_pose="{joints_pose}" />

        </Sequence>

</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree defines a sequence of actions to be executed by an agent. Initially, the agent performs "go1" action, followed by setting a value in the blackboard with the key "valueA" to 3. Then, it repeats the "go2" action a specified number of times based on the value of "valueA". After completing the repetitions, the agent executes the "go3" action.

Additionally, there is a separate section defining the available actions ("go1", "go2", "go3") within the tree.

Overall, this behavior tree orchestrates a series of actions for the agent, incorporating conditional repetition and blackboard interaction.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Sequence>
            <Action ID="go1"/>
            <SetBlackboard output_key="${valueA:s}" value="3"/>
            <Repeat num_cycles="${valueA:f}">
                <Action ID="go2"/>
            </Repeat>
            <Action ID="go3"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="go1"/>
        <Action ID="go2"/>
        <Action ID="go3"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>
