instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree depicts a series of actions for a system to execute in a specific order. The system will attempt to perform the actions "go2" and "go3" together, but if either fails, it will move on to the next set of actions. If "go4" fails, the system will proceed to "go5". Similarly, if "go8" fails, it will continue to "go9". However, if any action other than "go1" fails, the entire sequence will be considered a failure. This structure ensures that the system attempts each action in a predefined order and handles failures gracefully by moving on to the next action in the sequence.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Fallback>
            <ForceFailure>
                <Action ID="go1"/>
            </ForceFailure>
            <ForceFailure>
                <Sequence>
                    <Action ID="go2"/>
                    <Action ID="go3"/>
                </Sequence>
            </ForceFailure>
            <ForceFailure>
                <Sequence>
                    <ForceFailure>
                        <ForceFailure>
                            <Action ID="go4"/>
                        </ForceFailure>
                    </ForceFailure>
                    <Action ID="go5"/>
                </Sequence>
            </ForceFailure>
            <ForceFailure>
                <Sequence>
                    <Sequence>
                        <Action ID="go6"/>
                        <Action ID="go7"/>
                        <ForceFailure>
                            <Action ID="go8"/>
                        </ForceFailure>
                    </Sequence>
                    <Action ID="go9"/>
                </Sequence>
            </ForceFailure>
        </Fallback>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="go1"/>
        <Action ID="go2"/>
        <Action ID="go3"/>
        <Action ID="go4"/>
        <Action ID="go5"/>
        <Action ID="go6"/>
        <Action ID="go7"/>
        <Action ID="go8"/>
        <Action ID="go9"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed to execute a sequence of actions for a task. It begins by attempting to perform two actions, "go1" and "go2", repeatedly until successful. The number of attempts is determined by the value of "${valueQ}". Upon successful completion of these actions, it proceeds to execute "go3".

In summary, the behavior tree orchestrates a series of actions, ensuring that "go1" and "go2" are executed successfully before moving on to "go3". If any action fails, it will be retried based on the specified number of attempts.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Sequence>
            <RetryUntilSuccesful num_attempts="${valueQ}">
                <Sequence>
                    <Action ID="go1"/>
                    <Action ID="go2"/>
                </Sequence>
            </RetryUntilSuccesful>
            <Action ID="go3"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="go1"/>
        <Action ID="go2"/>
        <Action ID="go3"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates a robot's movement towards four different goals (Goal_a, Goal_b, Goal_c, Goal_d). The robot is programmed to first move towards Goal_a and then Goal_b in a repeated sequence for 10 cycles. This sequence can be interrupted if the "goC" or "goD" events are triggered. If interrupted, the robot will proceed to move towards Goal_c. After completing or being interrupted from the previous sequence, the robot will then move towards Goal_d.

In summary, the behavior tree outlines the robot's sequential movement towards multiple goals, with the ability to interrupt its current sequence based on specific events, ensuring adaptability in its navigation strategy.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute = "MainTree">
    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <Sequence>
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_a" value="0.00;0.00;0.0;1.0" />
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_b" value="1.00;1.533;0.0;1.0" />
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_c" value="1.588;2;0.0;1.0" />
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_d" value="1.4;0.000;0.0;1.0" />
            <Fallback>
                <ReactiveSequence>
                    <InterruptEvent event="goC"/>
                    <InterruptEvent event="goD"/>
                    <Repeat num_cycles="10">
                        <Sequence>
                            <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_a" />            
                            <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_b" />
                        </Sequence>
                    </Repeat>
                </ReactiveSequence>
                
                <ReactiveSequence> 
                    <InterruptEvent event="goD"/>         
                    <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_c" />
                </ReactiveSequence>
                       
                <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_d" />
            </Fallback>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>

    <BehaviorTree ID="MoveRobot">
        <Sequence name="SetGoal">
            <Nav2Client goal="{target}" />
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates the actions of a robot. The "MainTree" repeatedly executes a sequence of tasks, including generating random displacement and then invoking the "MoveAndShoot" behavior tree to move and take a photo while handling potential failures. The "MoveAndShoot" behavior tree utilizes a reactive sequence to ensure the robot moves and takes a photo in a coordinated manner, with the possibility of random failure.

Overall, the behavior tree controls the robot's movement and photography activities, ensuring that it continues to execute these tasks even in the face of potential failures. It demonstrates resilience by retrying failed actions and managing delays between cycles.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">

    <BehaviorTree ID="MoveAndShoot">
        <ReactiveSequence name="move_and_shoot_sequence">
            <!-- Non-uniform failure probability, good for test halting behavior of action/service -->
            <!-- Pinged at around 10Hz -->
            <RandomFailure probability="0.01"/>
            <!-- Test the service node -->
            <SnapPhotoNode server_name="/snap_photo" server_timeout="0" topic="test_topic"/>
            <!-- Test the action node -->
            <MoveDistanceNode server_name="/move_distance" server_timeout="100" cancel_timeout="0" distances="{distances}"/>
        </ReactiveSequence>
    </BehaviorTree>

    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <Delay delay_msec="5">
            <Repeat num_cycles="5">
                <Sequence>
                    <!-- Test remapping ports between trees -->
                    <RandomDisplacement displacement="{displacement}"/>
                    <!-- Keep this going in case of random failure -->
                    <RetryUntilSuccesful num_attempts="3">
                        <SubTree ID="MoveAndShoot" distances="displacement" node="node"/>
                    </RetryUntilSuccesful>
                </Sequence>
            </Repeat>
        </Delay>
    </BehaviorTree>

</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed to control a robotic system. It consists of multiple actions and decorators that orchestrate the robot's behavior. The main sequence involves the robot performing a series of tasks in a loop, with each task involving movement towards specific goals. These movements are repeated 10 times for each goal.

Additionally, there are various utility actions such as waiting for a specified duration, logging messages, performing mathematical operations, subscribing to topics, publishing messages, and interacting with ROS services.

Furthermore, the tree includes specialized actions for robot-specific tasks such as fire detection, extinguishing fires, window detection, takeoff, landing, and navigation to specific goals using Actionlib action servers.

Overall, the behavior tree encapsulates the logic required for the robot to perform a predefined set of tasks, handle interruptions, and interact with its environment through ROS messages and services.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Sequence>
            <Action name="WaitSeconds1" ID="WaitSeconds" duration="2"/>
            <ForceSuccess name="ForceSuccess1">
                <Repeat num_cycles="10">
                    <Action goal_name="stage_3_pos_final_1" name="GoToGoal1" action="/Make_Plan" ID="UPOGoToGoalByName" state="gpf1"/>
                </Repeat>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <Action name="WaitSeconds2" ID="WaitSeconds" duration="2"/>
            <ForceSuccess name="ForceSuccess2">
                <Repeat num_cycles="10">
                    <Action goal_name="stage_3_pos_final_2" name="GoToGoal2" action="/Make_Plan" ID="UPOGoToGoalByName" state="gpf2"/>
                </Repeat>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <Action name="WaitSeconds3" ID="WaitSeconds" duration="2"/>
            <ForceSuccess name="ForceSuccess3">
                <Repeat num_cycles="10">
                    <Action goal_name="stage_3_pos_final_3" name="GoToGoal3" action="/Make_Plan" ID="UPOGoToGoalByName" state="gpf3"/>
                </Repeat>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <Action name="WaitSecondsEnd" ID="WaitSeconds" duration="2"/>
            <ForceSuccess name="ForceSuccess4">
                <Repeat num_cycles="10">
                    <Action goal_name="stage_3_pos_final_4" name="GoToGoal4" action="/Make_Plan" ID="UPOGoToGoalByName" state="gpf4"/>
                </Repeat>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <Action name="WaitSecondsEnd" ID="WaitSeconds" duration="1"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="CallEmptyService">
            <input_port type="std::string" name="service">ROS service name</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="CheckBool">
            <input_port type="bool" name="input">Input boolean value</input_port>
        </Condition>
        <Action ID="CheckKey">
            <input_port type="std::string" name="no_key">Key to determine if key to say 'no' has benn pressed</input_port>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="yes_key">Key to determine if key to say 'yes' has been pressed</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="CompareNumbers">
            <input_port type="std::string" name="comparison_op">Comparison operator. Valid operators are <, >, <=, >=, == and !=</input_port>
            <input_port type="double" name="first">First operand</input_port>
            <input_port type="double" name="second">Second operand</input_port>
        </Condition>
        <Condition ID="CompareStrings">
            <input_port type="std::string" name="comparison_op">Comparison operator. Valid operators are <, >, <=, >=, == and !=</input_port>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="first">First operand</input_port>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="second">Second operand</input_port>
        </Condition>
        <Action ID="ConcatenateStrings">
            <input_port type="std::string" name="first">First string</input_port>
            <output_port type="std::string" name="output">Concatenated result string</output_port>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="second">Second string</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ConvertJsonToDouble">
            <input_port type="nlohmann::basic_json<std::map, std::vector, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, bool, long, unsigned long, double, std::allocator, nlohmann::adl_serializer>" name="input">Serialized ROS message</input_port>
            <output_port type="double" name="output">Output variable</output_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ConvertJsonToInt64">
            <input_port type="nlohmann::basic_json<std::map, std::vector, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, bool, long, unsigned long, double, std::allocator, nlohmann::adl_serializer>" name="input">Serialized ROS message</input_port>
            <output_port type="long" name="output">Output variable</output_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ConvertJsonToString">
            <input_port type="nlohmann::basic_json<std::map, std::vector, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, bool, long, unsigned long, double, std::allocator, nlohmann::adl_serializer>" name="input">Serialized ROS message</input_port>
            <output_port type="std::string" name="output">Output variable</output_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ConvertJsonToUint64">

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is quite simple. It consists of two main components: "BehaviorTree" and "collectTree". The "BehaviorTree" contains a single action "go1", while the "collectTree" includes a sequence of actions "go1" followed by "go2". Additionally, there is a "TreeNodesModel" which references the "collectTree", "go1", and "go2".

In summary, this behavior tree defines two sets of actions - one with a single action and another with a sequence of two actions. The "TreeNodesModel" serves as a reference to these actions and sequences.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Sequence>
            <Action ID="go1"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="collectTree">
        <Sequence>
            <Action ID="go1"/>
            <Action ID="go2"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <SubTree ID="collectTree"/>
        <Action ID="go1"/>
        <Action ID="go2"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree instructs an entity to perform two actions in sequence. First, it is directed to say "Hello World", and then to execute the action "SayHello". This indicates a simple task where the entity is expected to communicate a greeting message followed by another action related to saying hello.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="SayStuff">

    <BehaviorTree ID="SayStuff">
        <SequenceStar>
            <Action ID="SaySomething" message="Hello World"/>
            <Action ID="SayHello"/>
        </SequenceStar>
    </BehaviorTree>
    
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree defines the actions and conditions for controlling a robot. The main behavior tree, "BehaviorTree", consists of two main sequences. The first sequence uses reactive nodes to handle the robot's gripper based on the state of three different suction cups. If the left suction cup is not active, the robot waits for 3000 milliseconds; otherwise, it activates the left valve of the gripper.

The second sequence checks the states of the suction cups and activates the corresponding valves in the gripper accordingly: left, middle, or right. 

Additionally, there is another behavior tree called "TestSensors" that contains a sequence of conditions related to various sensors and actuators. These conditions are used to check the status of different components such as emergency stop, presence of objects, and the state of suction cups.

Overall, the behavior tree controls the robot's gripper based on the state of its suction cups and includes a separate tree for testing sensors and actuators.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Sequence>
            <ReactiveFallback>
                <ReactiveSequence>
                    <Inverter>
                        <Condition ID="IsVentouseGauche"/>
                    </Inverter>
                    <Action ID="Attendre" ms="3000"/>
                </ReactiveSequence>
                <Action ID="Pince" middle_valve="false" right_valve="false" left_valve="true"/>
            </ReactiveFallback>
            <Sequence>
                <Condition ID="IsVentouseGauche"/>
                <Action ID="Pince" middle_valve="false" right_valve="false" left_valve="true"/>
                <Condition ID="IsVentouseCentre"/>
                <Action ID="Pince" middle_valve="true" right_valve="false" left_valve="false"/>
                <Condition ID="IsVentouseDroite"/>
                <Action ID="Pince" middle_valve="false" right_valve="true" left_valve="false"/>
            </Sequence>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="TestSensors">
        <Sequence>
            <Inverter>
                <Condition ID="MinuterieNonEcoulee"/>
            </Inverter>
            <ForceSuccess>
                <Condition ID="IsCampViolet"/>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <ForceSuccess>
                <Condition ID="IsArretUrgence"/>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <ForceSuccess>
                <Condition ID="IsTirettePresente"/>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <ForceSuccess>
                <Condition ID="IsPaletCentre"/>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <ForceSuccess>
                <Condition ID="IsPaletDroit"/>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <ForceSuccess>
                <Condition ID="IsPaletGauche"/>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <ForceSuccess>
                <Condition ID="IsVentouseCentre"/>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <ForceSuccess>
                <Condition ID="IsVentouseDroite"/>
            </ForceSuccess>
            <ForceSuccess>
                <Condition ID="IsVentouseGauche"/>
            </ForceSuccess>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="AfficherLeScore"/>
        <Action ID="AjouterAuScore">
            <input_port default="1" name="score">Valeur Ã  ajouter au score</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="Aller">
            <input_port default="0" name="theta">Angle du robot (en degree)</input_port>
            <input_port default="0" name="x">Position absolue en X (en metre)</input_port>
            <input_port default="0" name="y">Position absolue en Y (en metre)</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="Attendre">
            <input_port default="1000" name="ms">Temps en millisecondes</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="Bras">
            <input_port default="0" name="angle_base">Angle moteur au plus pres de la base</input_port>
            <input_port default="0" name="angle_pince">Angle moteur au plus pres de la pince</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="DefinirLeScore">
            <input_port default="0" name="score">Valeur du score</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="DefinirTempsMinuterie">
            <input_port default="1398" name="seconds">Temps de la minuterie en secondes</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="InitialiserPosition"/>
        <Condition ID="IsArretUrgence"/>
        <Condition ID="IsCampViolet"/>
        <Condition ID="IsPaletCentre"/>
        <Condition ID="IsPaletDroit"/>
        <Condition ID="IsPaletGauche"/>
        <Condition ID="IsRobotEnMouvement"/>
        <Condition ID="IsTirettePresente"/>
        <Condition ID="IsVentouseCentre"/>
        <Condition ID="IsVentouseDroite"/>
        <Condition ID="IsVentouseGauche"/>
        <Action ID="LancerLaMinuterie">
            <input_port name="seconds"/>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="MinuterieNonEcoulee"/>
        <Action ID="Pince">
            <input_port default="false" name="left_valve"/>
            <input_port default="false" name="middle_valve"/>
            <input_port default="false" name="right_valve"/>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="ScoreInferieurA">
            <input_port default="1" name="score">Score</input_port>
        </Condition>
        <Condition ID="ScoreSuperieurA">
            <input_port default="0" name="score">Score</input_port>
        </Condition>
        <SubTree ID="TestSensors"/>
        <Action ID="VitesseConstante">
            <input_port default="0" name="angular_z">Vitesse de rotation en rad/s</input_port>
            <input_port default="0" name="linear_x">Vitesse dans le sens avant/arriere en m/s</input_port>
            <input_port default="0" name="linear_y">Vitesse dans le sens droite/gauche en m/s</input_port>
        </Action>
        <SubTree ID="campJaune"/>
        <SubTree ID="campViolet"/>
        <SubTree ID="initRobot"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed to control a robotic system for executing various actions related to motion planning and manipulation. The main task involves executing a sequence of actions, starting with the "ExecuteGroupPose" action that specifies a goal for the robot's arm. This action is part of a Sequence node, indicating that it should be performed in a sequential manner.

The TreeNodesModel section defines several specific actions that can be executed by the robot, such as adding collision boxes or planes, planning and executing trajectories, setting joint states, shifting positions, attaching and detaching objects, and removing collisions.

Overall, the behavior tree orchestrates the robot's movements and interactions with its environment, allowing it to perform complex tasks involving motion planning, manipulation, and collision handling. The "ExecuteGroupPose" action serves as the initial step in this process, followed by potential subsequent actions based on the robot's environment and task requirements.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Sequence>
            <Action ID="ExecuteGroupPose" goal="0 0 0 0 0 0 1" group_name="arm" is_absolute="0" service_name="execute_group_pose" tolerance="0.01"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="ExecuteAddCollisionBox">
            <input_port default="1" name="auto_suffix"/>
            <input_port default="box" name="box_name"/>
            <input_port default="{place_pose}" name="box_pose"/>
            <input_port default="0.2 0.2 0.2" name="box_size"/>
            <input_port default="arm" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port default="1" name="is_absolute">if true, the ref is the base_frame of group, otherwise the eef_frame</input_port>
            <input_port default="execute_add_box" name="service_name"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteAddCollisionPlane">
            <input_port default="0" name="auto_suffix"/>
            <input_port default="arm" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port default="ground" name="plane_name"/>
            <input_port default="0 0 1" name="plane_normal"/>
            <input_port default="0 0 0 0 0 0 1" name="plane_pose">Pose</input_port>
            <input_port default="execute_add_plane" name="service_name"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteAllPlans">
            <input_port default="0 0 0 0 0 0 1" name="all_poses">Poses for each group to visit, seperate with | for different groups</input_port>
            <input_port default="0" name="allow_collision"/>
            <input_port default="panda_arm" name="group_names"/>
            <input_port default="0" name="is_absolute"/>
            <input_port default="execute_all_plans" name="service_name"/>
            <input_port default="1" name="stamps"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteAllPoses">
            <input_port default="0" name="allow_collision"/>
            <input_port default="0 0 0 0 0 0 1" name="goals">Goals for each group to reach, seperate with ;</input_port>
            <input_port default="panda_arm" name="group_names">Names of groups to control, seperate with space</input_port>
            <input_port default="0" name="is_absolute"/>
            <input_port default="execute_all_poses" name="service_name"/>
            <input_port default="1" name="stamps">Time stamps for each group reaching the goal, seperate with space</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteAttachCollisionBox">
            <input_port name="box_name"/>
            <input_port name="box_pose"/>
            <input_port name="box_size"/>
            <input_port default="gripper" name="eef_group_name"/>
            <input_port default="arm" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port default="execute_attach_box" name="service_name"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteDetachCollision">
            <input_port default="arm" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port name="obj_name"/>
            <input_port default="execute_detach_object" name="service_name"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteGroupAngularJointStates">
            <input_port default="0 0 0 0 0 0 0" name="goal"/>
            <input_port default="panda_arm" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port default="execute_group_joint_states" name="service_name"/>
            <input_port default="0.01" name="tolerance"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteGroupLinearJointStates">
            <input_port default="0.04 0.04" name="goal"/>
            <input_port default="hand" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port default="execute_group_joint_states" name="service_name"/>
            <input_port default="0.001" name="tolerance"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteGroupPlan">
            <input_port default="0" name="allow_collision"/>
            <input_port default="panda_arm" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port default="0" name="is_absolute"/>
            <input_port default="0 0 0.1 0 0 0 1;0 0 -0.1 0 0 0 1" name="poses">Trajectory poses in plan. Each pose is relevant to the last pose.</input_port>
            <input_port default="execute_group_plan" name="service_name"/>
            <input_port default="2" name="stamp">Time stamp of the last pose in plan</input_port>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteGroupPose">
            <input_port default="0 0 0 0 0 0 1" name="goal"/>
            <input_port default="arm" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port default="0" name="is_absolute"/>
            <input_port default="execute_group_pose" name="service_name"/>
            <input_port default="0.01" name="tolerance"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteGroupPosition">
            <input_port default="0 0 0" name="goal"/>
            <input_port default="arm" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port default="0" name="is_absolute"/>
            <input_port default="execute_group_position" name="service_name"/>
            <input_port default="0.005" name="tolerance"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteGroupShift">
            <input_port default="z" name="axis">Could be x y z roll pitch yaw</input_port>
            <input_port default="0" name="goal"/>
            <input_port default="arm" name="group_name"/>
            <input_port default="0" name="is_absolute"/>
            <input_port default="execute_group_shift" name="service_name"/>
            <input_port default="0.01" name="tolerance"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ExecuteRemoveCollision">
            <input_port default="1" name="is_exact"/>
            <input_port name="obj_name"/>
            <input_port default="execute_remove_object" name="service_name"/>
        </Action>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates the navigation of a robot by continuously replanning its global path through an array of poses at a rate of 1 Hz. It includes recovery actions specific to planning, control, and general system issues. The "NavigateRecovery" node manages the recovery process with a maximum of 6 retries. Within this, the "NavigateWithReplanning" sequence uses a rate controller to limit the frequency of path computation and execution. It contains recovery nodes for computing paths through poses and following the computed path. These recovery nodes handle scenarios such as goal updates and clearing costmaps.

Additionally, the "RecoveryFallback" handles general recovery actions including clearing both local and global costmaps, spinning the robot, waiting, and backing up in a round-robin fashion. This ensures that the robot can recover from various issues it may encounter during navigation, ultimately enhancing its robustness and reliability.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz through an array of poses continuously
   and it also has recovery actions specific to planning / control as well as general system issues.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="6" name="NavigateRecovery">
      <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
        <RateController hz="0.333">
          <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="ComputePathThroughPoses">
            <ReactiveSequence>
              <RemovePassedGoals input_goals="{goals}" output_goals="{goals}" radius="0.5"/>
              <ComputePathThroughPoses goals="{goals}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
            </ReactiveSequence>
            <ReactiveFallback name="ComputePathThroughPosesRecoveryFallback">
              <GoalUpdated/>
              <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
            </ReactiveFallback>
          </RecoveryNode>
        </RateController>
        <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="FollowPath">
          <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>
          <ReactiveFallback name="FollowPathRecoveryFallback">
            <GoalUpdated/>
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
          </ReactiveFallback>
        </RecoveryNode>
      </PipelineSequence>
      <ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
        <GoalUpdated/>
        <RoundRobin name="RecoveryActions">
          <Sequence name="ClearingActions">
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
            <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
          </Sequence>
          <Spin spin_dist="1.57"/>
          <Wait wait_duration="5"/>
          <BackUp backup_dist="0.15" backup_speed="0.025"/>
        </RoundRobin>
      </ReactiveFallback>
    </RecoveryNode>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree represents a robot's navigation system that periodically replans its global path at 1 Hz and includes recovery actions. It consists of multiple recovery nodes to handle potential failures during navigation.

The "NavigateWithReplanning" sequence utilizes a rate controller to ensure the frequency of path planning, with a subsequence for computing the path to the goal using a grid-based planner. If this fails, it triggers recovery actions such as clearing the global costmap and waiting before retrying.

Another subsequence involves following the planned path using a specific controller, with recovery actions like clearing the local costmap and spinning if necessary.

If any of these sequences fail, the overall recovery node handles the situation by waiting for a duration before attempting navigation again.

Overall, the behavior tree ensures robust navigation by incorporating periodic replanning and recovery mechanisms to address potential obstacles or failures in the robot's path.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz and it also has
  recovery actions.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="2" name="NavigateRecovery">
      <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
        <RateController hz="1.0">
          <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="4" name="ComputePathToPose">
            <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
            <ReactiveFallback name="PathToPoseFallback">
              <GoalUpdated/>
              <RoundRobin name="GlobalPlannerRecoveryActions">
                <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
                <Wait wait_duration="2"/>
              </RoundRobin>
            </ReactiveFallback>
          </RecoveryNode>
        </RateController>
        <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="4" name="FollowPath">
          <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>
          <ReactiveFallback name="FollowPathFallback">
            <GoalUpdated/>
            <RoundRobin name="PlannerRecoveryActions">
              <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
              <Spin spin_dist="1.57"/>
            </RoundRobin>
          </ReactiveFallback>
        </RecoveryNode>
      </PipelineSequence>
      <ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
        <GoalUpdated/>
        <Wait wait_duration="5"/>
      </ReactiveFallback>
    </RecoveryNode>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates a series of tasks for a robot. It repeatedly executes a sequence of actions, including updating the planning scene, moving to specific locations, adjusting torso and head positions, scanning shelves, setting tray loci, updating the planning scene again, and pausing for 5 seconds. This process continues indefinitely as indicated by the num_cycles="-1" attribute in the Repeat node.

Overall, the robot is performing a looped set of operations that involve navigation, perception, manipulation, and coordination with its environment. The tasks seem to be related to inventory management or object manipulation within a defined space, possibly in a warehouse or similar setting.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">

    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Repeat num_cycles="-1">
            <Sequence>
                <TrayUpdatePlanningScene />
                <MoveBase goal="2.1;-2.0;0.0" />
                <MoveBase goal="2.1;-0.0;1.57" />
                <Sequence>
                    <TorsoControl relative_height="0.1" />
                    <HeadControl pitch="0.0" yaw="90.0" />
                    <ScanShelves tomato_can_stocking_target_poses="{tomato_can_stocking_target_poses}" />
                    <TraySetLoci tray_name="shelf" locus_poses="{tomato_can_stocking_target_poses}" occupied="false" />
                    <TrayUpdatePlanningScene />
                </Sequence>
                <Pause time_limit_sec="5" />
            </Sequence>
        </Repeat>
    </BehaviorTree>

</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates a robotic system to perform repetitive tasks in an indoor environment. The robot is programmed to continuously execute a sequence of actions, including moving to a specific location, adjusting its torso and head position, scanning a table for objects, processing the scan results, updating the planning scene, and pausing for specified durations between actions.

Specifically, the robot will repeatedly move to a designated location, adjust its torso and head, scan a table for objects, process the scan results to identify tomato cans, place the detected tomato cans on a tray named "table," update the planning scene with the new information, and then pause before repeating the entire sequence. This behavior is designed to automate the process of identifying and handling objects on a table within the robot's operational environment.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">

    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Repeat num_cycles="-1">
            <Sequence>
                <!-- <MoveBase goal="1.4;0;0"/> -->
                <MoveBase goal="2.3;-0.1;0"/>
                <Sequence>
                    <TorsoControl relative_height="0.95" />
                    <HeadControl pitch="0.0" yaw="140.0" />
                    <ScanTableStartScanning />
                    <Pause time_limit_sec="2"/>
                    <ScanTableGetResults detected_tomato_cans="{detected_tomato_cans}" />
                    <TraySetLoci tray_name="table" locus_poses="{detected_tomato_cans}" occupied="true" />
                    <TrayUpdatePlanningScene />
                    <Pause time_limit_sec="3"/>
                </Sequence>
            </Sequence>
        </Repeat>
    </BehaviorTree>

</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed for a robot's navigation system. It periodically replans the global path at 1 Hz and includes recovery actions in case of failures. The main sequence involves navigating with replanning, which consists of computing a path to a specific pose, following that path, and handling recovery if needed.

If there are issues with computing the path to the pose, it retries a certain number of times and performs recovery actions such as clearing the global costmap and waiting. Similarly, if there are problems with following the path, it retries and executes recovery actions like clearing the local costmap and spinning.

In case of overall failure or if the goal is updated, it enters a recovery fallback state where it waits for a specified duration before attempting navigation again. This behavior tree ensures robust navigation by incorporating periodic replanning and recovery strategies to handle unexpected obstacles or changes in the environment.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically at 1 Hz and it also has
  recovery actions.
-->
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="2" name="NavigateRecovery">
      <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
        <RateController hz="1.0">
          <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="4" name="ComputePathToPose">
            <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
            <ReactiveFallback name="PathToPoseFallback">
              <GoalUpdated/>
              <RoundRobin name="GlobalPlannerRecoveryActions">
                <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap"/>
                <Wait wait_duration="2"/>
              </RoundRobin>
            </ReactiveFallback>
          </RecoveryNode>
        </RateController>
        <RecoveryNode number_of_retries="4" name="FollowPath">
          <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>
          <ReactiveFallback name="FollowPathFallback">
            <GoalUpdated/>
            <RoundRobin name="PlannerRecoveryActions">
              <ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap"/>
              <Spin spin_dist="1.57"/>
            </RoundRobin>
          </ReactiveFallback>
        </RecoveryNode>
      </PipelineSequence>
      <ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
        <GoalUpdated/>
        <Wait wait_duration="5"/>
      </ReactiveFallback>
    </RecoveryNode>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree outlines a robotic task of moving from bin A to bin B and picking an item. It consists of three main components: MainTree, MoveToPredefinedPoint, and PickingItem. 

In the MainTree, the robot is programmed to first execute the MoveToPredefinedPoint behavior followed by the PickingItem behavior in sequence.

The MoveToPredefinedPoint behavior involves the robot performing the "go1" action to move from bin A to bin B.

The PickingItem behavior entails the robot executing the "AdjustTCPOrientation" action to adjust its tool center point orientation for picking up an item.

Overall, the behavior tree orchestrates the sequential execution of moving from one location to another and then performing a specific action at the destination.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <Sequence name="move from bin A to bin B">
            <SubTree ID="MoveToPredefinedPoint"/>
            <SubTree ID="PickingItem"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="MoveToPredefinedPoint">
        <Sequence name="move from bin A to bin B">
           <Action ID="go1"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="PickingItem">
        <Action ID="AdjustTCPOrientation"/>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="AdjustTCPOrientation"/>
        <Action ID="LinearMove"/>
        <Action ID="go1"/>
        <SubTree ID="MoveToPredefinedPoint"/>
        <SubTree ID="PickingItem"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
