        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates the actions of a robot, specifically for its arm movement. It begins by obtaining an array of poses and then selects a specific pose from the array. After selecting the pose, it commands the robot's arm to move to that position using Cartesian control.

The tree is designed to handle various tasks such as detecting blocks and faces, speaking, waiting for a specified duration, and moving the base. However, in this specific instance, it focuses on arm manipulation.

Overall, the behavior tree aims to guide the robot through a sequence of actions related to arm movement, utilizing the provided poses to perform specific tasks. This could be part of a larger system where the robot interacts with its environment or performs designated actions based on received instructions.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Sequence>
            <Action pose_array="poses" topic="poses" ID="GetPoseArray"/>
            <Action pose_array="{poses}" pose_stamped="pose" position_in_list="0" ID="SelectPose"/>
            <Action type="CARTESIAN" action_name="/vizzy/right_arm_cartesian_controller/cartesian_action" frame_id="base_footprint" pose="{pose}" ID="ArmCartesian"/>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="ArmCartesian">
            <input_port name="action_name"/>
            <input_port name="frame_id"/>
            <input_port name="pose"/>
            <input_port name="type"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="ArmRoutines">
            <input_port name="gesture"/>
            <input_port name="topic"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="Charge">
            <input_port name="action"/>
            <input_port name="action_name"/>
        </Action>
        <SubTree ID="ChargeST"/>
        <Action ID="CheckBattery">
            <output_port type="int" name="battery_state"/>
            <output_port type="double" name="percentage"/>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="service_name"/>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="CheckBool">
            <input_port name="variable"/>
        </Condition>
        <Action ID="CheckCharging">
            <output_port type="int" name="charging_state"/>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="service_name"/>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="CompareDouble">
            <input_port name="A"/>
            <input_port name="B"/>
            <input_port name="Condition"/>
        </Condition>
        <Condition ID="CompareInt">
            <input_port name="A"/>
            <input_port name="B"/>
            <input_port name="Condition"/>
        </Condition>
        <Action ID="DetectBlocks">
            <output_port type="social_cues::BlockList_<std::allocator<void> >" name="block_list"/>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="block_topic"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="DetectFaces">
            <output_port name="faceListOut"/>
            <input_port name="face_topic"/>
        </Action>
        <SubTree ID="ErrorGameState"/>
        <Action ID="FaceCounter">
            <input_port name="faceListIn"/>
            <input_port name="number_faces"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="GazeAtTarget">
            <input_port name="action_name"/>
            <input_port name="fixation_pose"/>
            <input_port name="frame_id"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="GetInt16">
            <output_port name="number"/>
            <input_port name="topic"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="GetPoseArray">
            <output_port name="pose_array"/>
            <input_port name="topic"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="MoveBase">
            <input_port name="action_name"/>
            <input_port name="frame_id"/>
            <input_port name="goal_pose"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="SelectBlock">
            <input_port type="social_cues::BlockList_<std::allocator<void> >" name="block_list"/>
            <output_port type="geometry_msgs::PoseStamped_<std::allocator<void> >" name="block_pose"/>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="position_in_list"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="SelectPose">
            <input_port name="pose_array"/>
            <output_port name="pose_stamped"/>
            <input_port name="position_in_list"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="Speak">
            <input_port type="std::string" name="action_name"/>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="language"/>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="utterance"/>
            <input_port type="std::string" name="voice"/>
        </Action>
        <Action ID="WaitForXSeconds">
            <input_port name="result" default="SUCCESS">Result after specified time: SUCCESS or FAILURE</input_port>
            <input_port name="seconds" default="5">Time in seconds</input_port>
        </Action>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates a robot's movement towards three specified goals (Goal_a, Goal_b, and Goal_c). Initially, the robot is directed to move towards Goal_a, followed by Goal_b, and this sequence is repeated 10 times. However, if the robot receives the "gohome" event during this sequence, it will interrupt its current task. After completing or interrupting the sequence, the robot is then instructed to move towards Goal_c.

To achieve these movements, the behavior tree utilizes the "MoveRobot" subtree, which contains instructions for setting the goal location and initiating the robot's movement using the MoveBase function.

Overall, the behavior tree outlines a sequential and repetitive task for the robot, with the ability to interrupt the sequence based on an external event, and ultimately guiding the robot to different specified locations.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute = "MainTree">
    <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <Sequence>
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_a" value="-0.579;-1.341;0.0" />
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_b" value="5.214;-1.533;0.0" />
            <SetBlackboard output_key="Goal_c" value="-1.588;1.253;0.0" />
            <Fallback>
                <ReactiveSequence>
                    <InterruptEvent event="gohome"/>
                    <Repeat num_cycles="10">
                        <Sequence>
                            <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_a" />
                            <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_b" />
                        </Sequence>
                    </Repeat>
                </ReactiveSequence>
                <Sequence>
                    <SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="Goal_c" />
                </Sequence>
            </Fallback>
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>

    <BehaviorTree ID="MoveRobot">
        <Sequence name="SetGoal">
            <MoveBase goal="{target}" />
        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree is designed for a robot to dynamically navigate to a specific location while continuously updating its path. The robot's movement is controlled by a pipeline sequence that includes a rate controller and a path following mechanism.

First, the goal updater updates the robot's goal pose based on input and outputs an updated goal. Then, it computes a path to this updated goal using a grid-based planner. The rate controller ensures that this process occurs at a specified frequency.

Once the path is computed, the robot follows this path using a path-following controller. This process continues until the robot reaches its destination or encounters a failure.

Overall, the behavior tree orchestrates the dynamic navigation of the robot by constantly updating its path towards the specified goal pose.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree follows a dynamic pose to a certain distance
-->

<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">

        <Sequence>
          <GoalUpdater input_goal="{goal}" output_goal="{updated_goal}">
            <ComputePathToPose goal="{updated_goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
          </GoalUpdater>
        </Sequence>
      </RateController>
      <KeepRunningUntilFailure>
        <FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath"/>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree outlines the task for a robot. Initially, it disables pose detection control and clears the global cost map for navigation. The robot is then directed to seek specific poses in a defined sequence. If the robot detects a person with high confidence, it sets a flag indicating success. Otherwise, it continues seeking the next pose, moving towards it, and performing various actions such as speaking and spinning. If the robot fails to find a person after all poses have been sought, it checks the flag and speaks accordingly. Finally, there is a sub-behavior tree "MoveRobot" that handles the navigation to specific targets.

In summary, the behavior tree orchestrates the robot's search for specific poses, interaction upon detecting a person, and appropriate responses if no person is found. It also manages the robot's movement using the "MoveRobot" sub-tree.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
	<BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
		<Sequence>
      <PoseDetectionControlAction enable="false" />
			<Nav2ClearGlobalCostMap />
			<RobotSeekInitAction search_poses="-4.3,-4,180.0;-4.7,-6.6,270.0;-6.0,-4.2,206.0" />
			<!-- RobotSeekInitAction search_poses="-4.3,-4,180.0;0.75,-3.7,206.0;0.71,-6.0,206.0;-4.7,-6.6,270.0;-6.0,-4.2,206.0;-6.4,-1.9,0.0;-8.0,1.5,90.0;-4.4,0.95,218.0"
				/ -->
			<!-- RobotSeekInitAction
				search_poses="-4.3,-4,180.0;-4.7,-6.6,270.0;-6.0,-4.2,206.0;-6.4,-1.9,0.0;-8.0,1.5,90.0;-4.4,0.95,218.0" />
			<SetBlackboard output_key="found" value="0" / -->
			<Fallback>
				<KeepRunningUntilFailure>
					<ReactiveSequence>
  					<Fallback>
							<Inverter>
							  <ObjectDetectionAction class="person" pose="detected_Pose" min_confidence="0.95" />
								<!-- HumanPoseDetect pose_lr_check="presence" expected_pose_left="" expected_pose_right=""
									detected_person="{detected_person}" pose_left_speech="{pose_left_speech}"
									pose_right_speech="{pose_right_speech}" / -->
							</Inverter>
							<ForceFailure>
								<SetBlackboard output_key="found" value="1" />
							</ForceFailure>
						</Fallback>
						<Sequence>
							<RobotSeekNextSearchPose next_goal="{next_goal}" goal_speech="{goal_speech}" />
							<SubTree ID="MoveRobot" target="next_goal" />
							<TextToSpeechActionClient msg="{goal_speech}" />
							<RobotSpin angle="359" velocity="0.5" />
							<TextToSpeechActionClient msg="I didn't see anyone." />
						</Sequence>
					</ReactiveSequence>
				</KeepRunningUntilFailure>
				<Sequence>
					<BlackboardCheckInt value_A="{found}" value_B="1" return_on_mismatch="FAILURE">
						<TextToSpeechActionClient msg="I found you!" />
					</BlackboardCheckInt>
				</Sequence>
			</Fallback>
		</Sequence>
	</BehaviorTree>

	<BehaviorTree ID="MoveRobot">
		<Sequence name="SetGoal">
			<Nav2Client goal="{target}" />
		</Sequence>
	</BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree consists of a single action where the robot is instructed to move to a specific location. The "SequenceStar" node indicates that this action can be repeated multiple times in a non-linear order, allowing for flexibility in the robot's movement.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree orchestrates a robotic system designed to continuously search for and navigate towards humans. The robot is programmed to repeat this process indefinitely. 

Upon initialization, the robot sets a server timeout and checks if it's the first run. It then attempts to find a human using various strategies, including rate-controlled searches, path planning, and recovery sequences. If a human is found, the robot navigates towards them while handling potential navigation failures through recovery actions such as clearing costmaps, spinning, and waiting.

If the robot fails to move to the last position or encounters errors during navigation, it triggers recovery mechanisms, updates its state, and resets certain parameters before retrying the navigation process. Additionally, the robot will keep attempting to find a human until successful, with intermittent delays and spins, and reset its internal state if unsuccessful.

Overall, the behavior tree governs the continuous operation of a robot searching for and navigating towards humans, employing robust error handling and recovery strategies to ensure reliable performance.
output:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
	<!-- ////////// -->
	<BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
		<Repeat num_cycles="9999999">
			<Fallback>
				<Sequence>
					<SetBlackboard output_key="server_timeout" value="10000" />
					<IsFirstRun name="isFirstRun" current_id="{current_id}" found="{found}" moved_flag="{moved_flag}" got_initial_goal_output="{got_initial_goal_output}" got_initial_goal_input="{got_initial_goal_output}" />
					<FindHuman name="findHuman1" server_timeout="10000" current_id="{current_id}" target_id="{current_id}" got_initial_goal_output="{got_initial_goal_output}" found="{found}" goal="{goal}" />
				</Sequence>
				<Sequence>
					<IsHumanFound name="isHumanFound1" found="{found}" />
					<PipelineSequence>
						<RateController hz="1.0">
							<Fallback>
								<FindHuman name="findHuman2" server_timeout="10000" current_id="{current_id}" target_id="{current_id}" got_initial_goal_output="{got_initial_goal_output}" found="{found}" goal="{goal}" />
								<Delay delay_msec="200">
									<FindHuman name="findHuman3" server_timeout="10000" current_id="{current_id}" target_id="{current_id}" got_initial_goal_output="{got_initial_goal_output}" found="{found}" goal="{goal}" />
								</Delay>
							</Fallback>
						</RateController>
						<RecoveryNode number_of_retries="6" name="NavigateRecovery">
							<PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
								<RateController hz="1.0">
									<RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="ComputePathToPose">
										<Sequence>
											<GoalUpdater input_goal="{goal}" output_goal="{updated_goal}">
												<ComputePathToPose goal="{updated_goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased" />
											</GoalUpdater>
											<TruncatePath distance="1.6" input_path="{path}" output_path="{truncated_path}" />
										</Sequence>
										<ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap" />
									</RecoveryNode>
								</RateController>
								<RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="FollowPath">
									<FollowPath path="{truncated_path}" controller_id="FollowPath" />
									<ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap" />
								</RecoveryNode>
							</PipelineSequence>
							<ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
								<GoalUpdated />
								<SequenceStar name="RecoveryActions">
									<ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap" />
									<ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap" />
									<Spin spin_dist="3.14" />
									<Wait wait_duration="5" />
								</SequenceStar>
							</ReactiveFallback>
						</RecoveryNode>
					</PipelineSequence>
				</Sequence>
				<Sequence>
					<Fallback>
						<HasMoved name="hasMovedToLastPosition" moved_flag="{moved_flag}" />
						<Sequence>
							<RecoveryNode number_of_retries="6" name="NavigateRecovery">
								<PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
									<RateController hz="1.0">
										<RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="ComputePathToPose">
											<GoalUpdater input_goal="{goal}" output_goal="{updated_goal}">
												<ComputePathToPose goal="{updated_goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased" />
											</GoalUpdater>
											<ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Context" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap" />
										</RecoveryNode>
									</RateController>
									<RecoveryNode number_of_retries="1" name="FollowPath">
										<FollowPath path="{path}" controller_id="FollowPath" />
										<ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Context" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap" />
									</RecoveryNode>
								</PipelineSequence>
								<ReactiveFallback name="RecoveryFallback">
									<GoalUpdated />
									<SequenceStar name="RecoveryActions">
										<ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearLocalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="local_costmap/clear_entirely_local_costmap" />
										<ClearEntireCostmap name="ClearGlobalCostmap-Subtree" service_name="global_costmap/clear_entirely_global_costmap" />
										<Spin spin_dist="3.14" />
										<Wait wait_duration="5" />
									</SequenceStar>
								</ReactiveFallback>
							</RecoveryNode>
							<SetBlackboard output_key="moved_flag" value="true" />
							<ResetKalman name="resetKalman" server_timeout="10000" />
						</Sequence>
					</Fallback>
					<Fallback>
						<RetryUntilSuccesful num_attempts="20">
							<Sequence>
								<Delay delay_msec="300">
									<Spin spin_dist="0.5" />
								</Delay>
								<FindHuman name="findHuman4" server_timeout="10000" current_id="{current_id}" target_id="{current_id}" got_initial_goal_output="{got_initial_goal_output}" found="{found}" goal="{goal}" />
								<SetBlackboard output_key="moved_flag" value="false" />
							</Sequence>
						</RetryUntilSuccesful>
						<Sequence>
							<SetBlackboard output_key="got_initial_goal_output" value="false" />
							<SetBlackboard output_key="current_id" value="-1" />
						</Sequence>
					</Fallback>
				</Sequence>
			</Fallback>
		</Repeat>
	</BehaviorTree>
	<!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input: The behavior tree orchestrates a robot's navigation with periodic global path replanning based on its speed. It utilizes a pipeline sequence that involves a speed controller and a path following component. The speed controller adjusts the frequency of global path replanning in proportion to the robot's speed, ensuring smoother navigation at varying speeds. The ComputePathToPose task calculates the path to the specified goal using the GridBased planner, and the resulting path is then followed by the robot using the FollowPath task. This approach enables the robot to dynamically adjust its navigation strategy based on its current speed, enhancing its ability to navigate through the environment effectively while considering its velocity constraints.
output:
<!--
  This Behavior Tree replans the global path periodically proprortional to speed.
-->

<root main_tree_to_execute="MainTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
    <PipelineSequence name="NavigateWithReplanning">
      <SpeedController min_rate="0.1" max_rate="1.0" min_speed="0.0" max_speed="0.26" filter_duration="0.3">
        <ComputePathToPose goal="{goal}" path="{path}" planner_id="GridBased"/>
      </SpeedController>
      <FollowPath path="{path}"  controller_id="FollowPath"/>
    </PipelineSequence>
  </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree represents a robotic system that continuously repeats the pursuit of goals. The robot is programmed to either place an item if it is holding one or pick up an item if it sees one. This process is repeated indefinitely. Additionally, there is an initialization step represented by the "Init" behavior tree, which involves printing "Initialize". The system also includes various actions and conditions such as AlwaysRunning, HoldingItem, SeeItem, Pick, Place, and Print.

In summary, the behavior tree outlines a continuous loop where the robot performs tasks based on certain conditions - placing an item if already holding one and picking up an item if it sees one. It also includes an initialization step.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
        <Repeat num_cycles="-1">
            <Fallback name="Pursue Goals">
                <Sequence name="Place Item">
                    <Condition ID="HoldingItem" name="Holding an Item"/>
                    <Action ID="Place" name="Place it"/>
                </Sequence>
                <Sequence name="Remove Item">
                    <Condition ID="SeeItem" name="See an Item"/>
                    <Action ID="Pick" name="Pick it up"/>
                </Sequence>
            </Fallback>
        </Repeat>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <BehaviorTree ID="Init">
        <Action ID="Print" message="Initialize"/>
    </BehaviorTree>
    <!-- ////////// -->
    <TreeNodesModel>
        <Action ID="AlwaysRunning"/>
        <Condition ID="HoldingItem"/>
        <SubTree ID="Init"/>
        <Action ID="Pick"/>
        <Action ID="Place"/>
        <Action ID="Print">
            <input_port name="message"/>
        </Action>
        <Condition ID="SeeItem"/>
    </TreeNodesModel>
    <!-- ////////// -->
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.

The behavior tree outlines a series of tasks for a robotic system. The main task involves the robot executing a sequence of actions, including resetting its components, picking up purple atoms, emptying a left barrel, and taking chaos. Each of these tasks is further broken down into subtasks, such as moving to specific positions, adjusting orientations, picking up items, and performing U-turns. Additionally, there are global subtrees for common actions like resetting components and handling barrels on both the left and right sides.

The "PickAllPurpleAtoms" subtree involves a complex sequence of movements to pick up multiple atoms from different positions and then perform a U-turn before proceeding. Similarly, the "EmptyBarrelLeft" subtree details the process of emptying a barrel by pushing items out at various positions.

Overall, the behavior tree orchestrates a series of intricate robotic actions, encompassing precise movements, object manipulation, and navigation to accomplish the specified tasks efficiently.

            <Turn name="towards chaos" angle="22"/>
            <MoveAhead name="move ahead" distance="500"/>
            <Turn name="towards chaos" angle="133"/>
            <MoveAhead name="move ahead" distance="1200"/>

        </Sequence>
    </BehaviorTree>
</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree outlines the actions for a robot's navigation and localization. The robot is programmed to perform a sequence of movements, including setting its initial pose, activating localization, and navigating to specific positions. It also includes actions such as triggering global localization, loading maps, approaching locations, orienting the robot, and joystick navigation.

The SequenceStar indicates that the robot will execute the specified movements in a sequential manner, but it allows for flexibility by not requiring all actions to be completed before moving on to the next one. This means that some actions can be skipped or interrupted based on certain conditions.

Overall, the behavior tree orchestrates the robot's navigation and localization tasks, allowing it to move to predefined positions, interact with the environment, and manage its localization and mapping processes.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute="BehaviorTree">
  <BehaviorTree ID="BehaviorTree">
    <SequenceStar>
      <!--	    
      <initNavigation />
      <getBasePose x="{x_}" y="{y_}" yaw="{yaw_}" />        
      <triggerGlobalLocalization />
      <setRobotPose x="0" y="0" yaw="0" />
      <activateLocalization />
      <startReactiveNavigation />
      <stopReactiveNavigation />
      <moveRoboterPosition x="1000" y="0" approachRadius="50"/>
      <moveRoboterPosition x="1100" y="0" approachRadius="50"/>
      <moveRoboterPosition x="1200" y="0" approachRadius="50"/>
      !-->
      <moveRoboterPosition x="-2100" y="0" approachRadius="50"/>
      <!--	   
      <getBaseCharging charging="{charging_}"/> 
      <peoplerecognition />            
      <moveRoboterPosition x="1000" y="2000" approachRadius="10"/>            
      <loadNavigationMap mapname="navigation-map" />
      <approachLocation locationId="1"/>
      <loadMap mapname="localization-map" />                        
      <moveRoboterBackwardsLocation locationID="1"/>
      <moveRoboterBackwardsRelative dist="500"/>
      <moveRoboterOrientateRobotAbs angleDeg="1"/>
      <moveRoboterOrientateRobotRel angleDeg="2"/>
      <approachLocation locationId="4"/>
      <approachLocation locationId="1"/>
      <approachWall />
      <startJoystickNavigation />
      <stopJoystickNavigation />
      <deactivateLocalization />
    !-->
    </SequenceStar>
  </BehaviorTree>

  <TreeNodesModel>
    <Action ID="initNavigation"/>
    <Action ID="loadNavigationMap">
      <input_port default="navigation-map" name="mapname"/>
    </Action>
    <Action ID="loadMap"/>
    <Action ID="triggerGlobalLocalization"/>
    <Action ID="setRobotPose">
      <input_port default="0" name="x"/>
      <input_port default="0" name="y"/>
      <input_port default="0" name="yaw"/>
    </Action>
    <Action ID="activateLocalization"/>
    <Action ID="startReactiveNavigation"/>
    <Action ID="stopReactiveNavigation"/>
    <Action ID="moveRoboterPosition">
      <input_port default="0" name="x"/>
      <input_port default="0" name="y"/>
      <input_port default="50" name="approachRadius"/>
    </Action>
    <Action ID="approachLocation">
      <input_port default="1" name="locationId"/>
    </Action>
    <Action ID="moveRoboterBackwardsLocation"/>
    <Action ID="moveRoboterBackwardsRelative"/>
    <Action ID="moveRoboterOrientateRobotAbs"/>
    <Action ID="moveRoboterOrientateRobotRel"/>
    <Action ID="approachWall"/>
    <Action ID="startJoystickNavigation"/>
    <Action ID="stopJoystickNavigation"/>
    <Action ID="deactivateLocalization"/>
    <Action ID="peoplerecognition"/>
    <Action ID="getPersonPose">
      <output_port default="{x_}" name="x"/>
      <output_port default="{y_}" name="y"/>
      <output_port default="{yaw_}" name="yaw"/>
    </Action>
    <Action ID="getBaseCharging">
      <output_port default="{charging}" name="charging"/>
    </Action>
    <Action ID="VariationAction">
      <input_port default="{value}" name="value"/>
      <input_port default="{key}" name="key"/>
    </Action>
  </TreeNodesModel>

</root>

instruction: You will be provided a summary of a task performed by a behavior tree, and your objective is to express this behavior tree in XML format.
input:
The behavior tree outlines the decision-making process for a character in a game when under attack. The character has various responses based on its current state.

When under attack, the character first checks if it has ammo. If not, it will prioritize finding ammo before fighting back. If it has ammo, it will assess its health status. If the character's health is low, it will attempt to dodge and fight back. If not, it will proceed with tracking and attacking the enemy.

If the character is not under direct attack, it will focus on tracking and attacking any visible enemies. However, if the character's health is low, it will prioritize dodging and then engage in combat.

Overall, the behavior tree ensures that the character responds appropriately to different scenarios, considering factors such as ammo availability, health status, and enemy visibility.
output:
<root main_tree_to_execute = "MainTree" >
     <BehaviorTree ID="MainTree">
        <Fallback name="root_sequence">
            
            <Fallback name="when under attack">
                <Fallback name="when under attack">
                    
                    <NoAmmo name="no_ammo"/>

                    <Sequence name="fight_back">
                        <LowHP name="low_hp"/>
                        <Dodge name="dodge"/>
                    </Sequence>
                    
                </Fallback>

                    <UnderAttack name="under_attack"/>
                    <Dodge name="dodge"/>
            </Fallback>

            <Sequence name="fight_back">
                <LowHP name="low_hp"/>
                <Dodge name="dodge"/>
                <Track name="track"/>
                <Attack name="attack"/>
            </Sequence>

                <LowHP name="low_hp"/>
                <Track name="track"/>
                <Attack name="attack"/>
            

            <Sequence name="fight_back">
                <LowHP name="low_hp"/>
                <EnamyVisable name="enamy_visable"/>
                <Track name="track"/>
                <Attack name="attack"/>
            </Sequence>

            <Sequence name="fight">
                <EnamyVisable name="enamy_visable"/>
                <Track name="track"/>
                <Attack name="attack"/>
            </Sequence>

        </Fallback>
     </BehaviorTree>
 </root>
